Clarifying tawaf rulings and supplications
Tawaf al-ifadah is valid on the 14th of Dhu al-Hijjah and beyond, though it's better to do it earlier. If done before travel, it counts for the farewell tawaf. Regarding a child in tawaf, both the carrier and the child count if they both intend to make tawaf. An illiterate person can substitute personal supplications for specific verses they don't understand.

Clarifying rulings on personal acts and funeral preparations
It’s good to teach someone du’as and supplications, encouraging them to recite whatever they’ve memorized from the Quran. As for shaving or shortening while in ihram, doing it oneself doesn’t contradict the Sunnah, though having someone else do it is fine too. Regarding funeral matters, only men prepare a man’s body and only women prepare a woman’s, with exceptions for spouses.

Ruling on Hajj, debts, and tamattu' handling
Men have an obligation to perform funeral prayers, while women are not required for congregational prayers. Regarding Hajj, if someone has debts, it’s recommended they seek permission before performing Hajj, and it’s better to reduce their debt first. I need to translate the provided Arabic text to English while keeping segment IDs like P338. I will use ALA-LC transliteration for narrator names in the chain, but not for the hadith content. I'll also ensure the right phrasing, using "Allah" instead of "God", and ensure all headings and content are translated with no Arabic words left in the text except for ﷺ. Three internal revisions will help.

Deciding on transliteration for narrators' names
I need to transliterate specific names in the narration chain using ALA-LC (e.g., Abd Allāh, Muḥammad, Mālik). However, the instruction specifies to transliterate only the narrator names in the chain, not the textual content. Outside the chain, for scholar names, I should likely stick to ALA-LC transliteration, but I’m a bit unsure about whether to forgo transliteration for some names like Abdul Muhsin al-Abbad.

Deciding on transliteration and formatting rules
The instruction specifies that ALA-LC transliteration should only be used for narrator names within the chain, not outside it. Thus, I'll use diacritics for narrator names in the chain but simplify other terms (e.g., Abu Dawud) without diacritics. For headings, I’ll keep them in proper case and include necessary translations in parentheses. I’ll translate bracketed portions, but I’ll likely keep the brackets for clarity.

Translating and formatting hadith excerpts
I’ll replicate the bracketed hadith excerpt after “the author said: [ ... ]”, translating the content inside the brackets (including the chain with the narrators). I will transliterate narrator names in the chain using ALA-LC, just like in the example provided. To avoid tool truncation, I'll split the long lines into smaller chunks—around 80 characters each—so everything can be printed fully without cutting off. This will help ensure I capture all the content without missing any details, especially if the tool truncates lines longer than 200 characters.

Splitting and printing long lines in chunks
def show_chunks(s, n=80):
    for i in range(0,len(s),n):
        print(s[i:i+n])
print("Line13:")
show_chunks(lines[13],80)
print("\nLine14:")
show_chunks(lines[14],80)

After Sālim was treated as a son but the limits of this status were clarified, the wife of Abū Ḥudhayfah, Sahlah, nursed him to establish a proper familial relationship.

For example, "{الزَّانِي لا يَنكِحُ إلَّا زَانِيَةً} [النور: ٣]" should become, "The fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress...". Regarding "الزاني," "fornicator" fits best, and "fornicatress" for females. For terms like "بغي" (prostitute), I’ll use "prostitute" to preserve technical accuracy.

Translating hadith terminology carefully
In topics like jarh wa ta'dil, terms like "thiqa" (trustworthy) or "ṣadūq" (truthful) are common, but how should I present them? The instructions don't forbid transliteration of technical terms, so "thiqa" and "ṣadūq" might be fine to use. I’ll be cautious about context and avoid diacritics, following guidelines about how to handle Arabic terms.

Translating and formatting Arabic text for narrations
translation = """P6704 - Allah the Exalted’s statement: (The fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress or an idolatress)

P6705 - Explanation of the ḥadīth of the Prophet ﷺ forbidding Marthad from marrying the prostitute ʿAnāq
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: Concerning Allah the Exalted’s statement: {The fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress} (al-Nur: 3).
Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī narrated to us; Yaḥyā narrated to us, from ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas, from ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb, from his father, from his grandfather, may Allah be pleased with him, that Marthad ibn Abī Marthad al-Ghanawī used to carry captives in Makkah. There was in Makkah a prostitute called ʿAnāq, and she had been his companion. He said: (I came to the Prophet ﷺ and said: O Messenger of Allah! Shall I marry ʿAnāq? He remained silent regarding me. Then it was revealed: {The fornicatress—none marries her except a fornicator or an idolater} (al-Nur: 3). So he called me, recited it to me, and said: Do not marry her).]
Imam Abu Dawud al-Sijistani, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: Concerning Allah the Exalted’s statement: {The fornicatress—none marries her except a fornicator or an idolater} (al-Nur: 3).]
This noble verse indicates that the fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress or an idolatress, and the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater. Abu Dawud mentioned this chapter heading and cited this ḥadīth under it to make clear that marriage to a fornicatress is not permissible, due to the Prophet’s ﷺ prohibition of it.

P6706 - The ruling on marrying a fornicatress and the statements of the scholars concerning it
The scholars have differed regarding the ruling of marrying a fornicatress. Some of them said that it is permissible for a chaste man to marry a fornicatress, because she is among the slave-women of the Muslims and among the unmarried women about whom Allah the Exalted said: {Marry off the unmarried among you} (al-Nur: 32); so that includes fornicatresses and others besides fornicatresses.
Some of the people of knowledge said that the chaste man does not marry the fornicatress; rather, only a fornicator like her marries her. In the ḥadīth that comes after this there occurs: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him). Its meaning, then, is that the chaste man does not marry the fornicatress, and the fornicator may marry the fornicatress, because their occupying themselves with what is lawful is better than their occupying themselves with what is unlawful.
Among the scholars are those who said that this noble verse is not about marriage, but rather it is about intercourse; its intent is that the fornicator does not have intercourse with a fornicatress or an idolatress—meaning, he does not commit fornication except with a fornicatress or an idolatress. So “nikāḥ” here is meant as intercourse, because Allah said: “except a fornicator or an idolater.” They said: the idolater has been mentioned, and an idolater can in no case contract marriage to a Muslim woman; it is not permissible for an idolater to marry a Muslim woman, nor is it permissible for a Muslim woman to marry an idolater. So they said: “nikāḥ” here is meant as intercourse. On this, the fornicator does not have intercourse except with a fornicatress—meaning, an immoral woman like him—or an idolatress who does not acknowledge lawful and unlawful. Likewise the reverse: “and the fornicatress—none has intercourse with her except a fornicator” like her “or an idolater” who does not distinguish between lawful and unlawful and deems fornication lawful.
They said: so the mention of the idolater here indicates that what is meant is intercourse.
But the ḥadīth the author cited here regarding the reason for the revelation of the verse—that the Messenger ﷺ recited it to him and said: (Do not marry her)—indicates that what is meant is marriage.
Our shaykh, Shaykh Muhammad al-Amin al-Shinqiti, may Allah have mercy on him, spoke about this verse in Adwa’ al-Bayan and said: this is among the most difficult issues, because the contextual indicator in the verse shows that what is meant by “nikāḥ” is intercourse, while the reason for revelation shows that what is meant by “nikāḥ” is marriage. He said: escaping—meaning, from this difficulty—is hard and is not achieved except with a kind of strain and contrivance. Then he pointed to something of that and said: “nikāḥ” is carried as a shared term between the two meanings: it is used for intercourse and it is used for marriage; so what is meant by it is marriage in one respect and intercourse in another.
The meaning of that is that if what is intended by it is intercourse in fornication, that is due to the indication of the mention of the idolater; so what is intended is intercourse due to the contextual indicator of mentioning the idolater. And the ḥadīth in which the Prophet ﷺ forbade him to marry her indicates that what is intended is marriage. Thus the verse is explained by both meanings and carried on both meanings that the wording indicates by its shared usage: intercourse and marriage.
The upshot is that marriage to a fornicatress by a chaste man is not permissible, as the ḥadīth indicates. As for the marriage of a fornicator to a fornicatress, it is allowable, due to his ﷺ statement: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him) in the forthcoming ḥadīth. His statement: “flogged” means that his fornication has become apparent and established by the presence of flogging for it; so the fornicator whose fornication has been established does not marry except one like him.
What appears is that the chaste man does not marry the immoral fornicatress; as for the fornicator, he marries her instead of the two of them occupying themselves with what is unlawful.
As for the ḥadīth, it contains that Marthad ibn Abī Marthad al-Ghanawī came to the Prophet ﷺ, and he used to carry captives from Makkah to Madinah. There was in Makkah a prostitute called ʿAnāq, and she had been his companion. He sought the Prophet’s ﷺ permission to marry her, so he recited the verse to him and said to him: (Do not marry her). This indicates that it is not permissible for the chaste man to marry the fornicatress, and that the fornicator may marry the fornicatress who is like him. As for the idolater, it is not permissible for him to marry a Muslim woman at all, due to the texts of the Book and the Sunnah regarding that.
What is meant by the chaste man not marrying the fornicatress is before her repentance. As for when she repents, then repentance wipes out what came before it, and Allah the Exalted accepts repentance from whoever repents; and the chaste man may marry her.

P6707 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the ḥadīth of the Prophet ﷺ forbidding Marthad from marrying the prostitute ʿAnāq
His statement: [Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī narrated to us.]
Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī is trustworthy; Abu Dawud and al-Nasa’i narrated from him.
[Yaḥyā narrated to us.]
He is Yaḥyā ibn Saʿīd al-Qaṭṭān, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas.]
ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas is truthful; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb.]
He is ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb ibn Muḥammad ibn ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿAmr ibn al-ʿĀṣ; he is truthful. Al-Bukhari narrated from him in the treatise on recitation, and the authors of the Sunan.
[From his father.]
He is Shuʿayb; he is truthful. Al-Bukhari narrated from him in the treatise on recitation and in al-Adab al-Mufrad, and the authors of the Sunan.
[From his grandfather.]
He is Shuʿayb’s grandfather, and he is ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿAmr ibn al-ʿĀṣ, may Allah be pleased with them both, the noble Companion—one of the four ʿAbd Allāhs among the Companions of the Prophet ﷺ. The authors of the Six Books narrated his ḥadīth.

P6708 - Explanation of the ḥadīth: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him)
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Musaddad and Abū Muʿammar said: ʿAbd al-Wārith narrated to us, from Ḥabīb—ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb narrated to me, from Saʿīd al-Maqburī, from Abū Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him).]
Abu Dawud cited the ḥadīth of Abū Hurayrah: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him). This indicates that the fornicator marries the fornicatress, and that is in the state where both are not repentant. As for when they have repented, then repentance wipes out what came before it; the chaste man may marry the fornicatress if she repents, and likewise the reverse.
His statement: “flogged” means: the one upon whom the legal punishment has been carried out and whose fornication has been established. It has no contrary implication in the sense that the one who was not flogged would not be like that; rather, he is the same. It only mentioned “flogged” because through it the existence of fornication is established. Flogging is an expiation for him, but if he does not repent then it is an expiation for the sin that occurred from him only; as for if he persists, then the flogging does not expiate his persistence, nor is he married to a chaste woman. But if it happens that a fornicator contracts marriage to a chaste woman, the contract is valid, and it is not said that the contract is invalid—though he is not a suitable match for her.
As for the chaste man, many scholars permitted him to marry the fornicatress, using as evidence Allah the Exalted’s statement: {Marry off the unmarried among you} (al-Nur: 32).

P6709 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the ḥadīth: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him)
His statement: [He said: Musaddad narrated to us.]
He is Musaddad ibn Musarhad, trustworthy; al-Bukhari, Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and al-Nasa’i narrated from him.
[And Abū Muʿammar.]
He is ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿAmr ibn Abī al-Ḥajjāj, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[ʿAbd al-Wārith narrated to us.]
He is ʿAbd al-Wārith ibn Saʿīd al-ʿAnbarī, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Ḥabīb.]
He is Ḥabīb al-Muʿallim, truthful; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb, from Saʿīd al-Maqburī.]
ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb has already been mentioned. Saʿīd al-Maqburī is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Abū Hurayrah.]
He is ʿAbd al-Raḥmān ibn Ṣakhr al-Dawsī, the Companion of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and the most prolific of his Companions in ḥadīth without exception—may Allah be pleased with him.
And Abū Muʿammar said: Ḥabīb al-Muʿallim narrated to me, from ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb.
Meaning: the wording he cited is upon the wording of the first shaykh, Musaddad. Then he informed about the second shaykh: the narration from Abū Muʿammar came with the additional word “al-Muʿallim” appended to Ḥabīb. Also, the first was with the wording “from,” while here it is with the wording of direct narration.

P6710 - A man frees his slave-girl, then marries her

P6711 - Explanation of the ḥadīth: (Whoever frees his slave-girl, then marries her, has two rewards)
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: A man frees his slave-girl, then marries her.
Hannād ibn al-Sarī narrated to us; ʿAbthar narrated to us, from Muṭarrif, from ʿĀmir, from Abū Burdah, from Abū Mūsā, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (Whoever frees his slave-girl and marries her has two rewards).]
Abu Dawud cited this chapter heading—[Chapter: A man frees his slave-girl and marries her]—meaning: that this is valid and contains tremendous reward. That is because the Prophet ﷺ said, as in the ḥadīth of Abū Mūsā: (He has two rewards), meaning: a reward for emancipating her and a reward for his kindness to her through emancipation and marriage. He married her, and she came to have a right to an allotted turn, after previously having no allotted turn. He treated her well by transferring her from a state in which she had no allotted turn to a state in which she is among the wives who are allotted turns. So he has two rewards: a reward for emancipating her and his kindness to her through emancipation, and a reward for his kindness to her through marriage and her becoming among his wives who have the right to an allotted turn.

P6712 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the ḥadīth: (Whoever frees his slave-girl, then marries her, has two rewards)
His statement: [Hannād ibn al-Sarī narrated to us.]
He is Hannād ibn al-Sarī Abū al-Sarī, trustworthy. Al-Bukhari narrated his ḥadīth in Khalq Afʿāl al-ʿIbād, and so did Muslim and the authors of the Sunan.
[ʿAbthar narrated to us.]
ʿAbthar is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Muṭarrif.]
He is Muṭarrif ibn Ṭarīf, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿĀmir.]
He is ʿĀmir ibn Sharāḥīl al-Shaʿbī, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Abū Burdah.]
He is Abū Burdah ibn Abī Mūsā al-Ashʿarī, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Abū Mūsā.]
He is Abū Mūsā al-Ashʿarī ʿAbd Allāh ibn Qays, may Allah be pleased with him. The authors of the Six Books narrated his ḥadīth. Thus, all the men of this chain are narrated from by the authors of the Six Books except for Hannād; al-Bukhari did not narrate from him in the Ṣaḥīḥ, but he narrated from him in Khalq Afʿāl al-ʿIbād.

P6713 - Explanation of the ḥadīth of the Prophet’s ﷺ emancipating Safiyyah and making her emancipation her dower
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [ʿAmr ibn ʿAwn narrated to us; Abū ʿAwānah informed us, from Qatādah and ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz ibn Ṣuhayb, from Anas ibn Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him: (that the Prophet ﷺ emancipated Safiyyah, may Allah be pleased with her, and made her emancipation her dower).]
Abu Dawud cited the ḥadīth of Anas ibn Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet ﷺ married Safiyyah and made her emancipation her dower. Safiyyah is the daughter of Huyayy ibn Akhtab, may Allah be pleased with her, the Mother of the Believers. She had been a slave-girl, so he emancipated her, and the Prophet ﷺ made her emancipation her dower. This indicates what the author translated the chapter for: emancipation and marriage, and that by doing so he has shown two kinds of kindness, and that it is permissible to make emancipation a dower because it is a favor he bestowed upon her.
The scholars differed as to whether this is specific to the Messenger ﷺ or whether it is for him and others. Saying that it is a special characteristic requires evidence; the correct view is that it is allowable and permissible, and that it is not among the special characteristics of the Messenger ﷺ.
His statement: (He emancipated Safiyyah and made her emancipation her dower) means: he emancipated her and married her, and her emancipation is her dower.

P6714 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the ḥadīth of the Prophet’s ﷺ emancipating Safiyyah and making her emancipation her dower
His statement: [ʿAmr ibn ʿAwn narrated to us.]

[Abū ʿAwānah informed us.]
He is al-Waḍḍāḥ ibn ʿAbd Allāh al-Yashkurī, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Qatādah.]
He is Qatādah ibn Diʿāmah al-Sadūsī al-Baṣrī, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[And ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz ibn Ṣuhayb.]
ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz ibn Ṣuhayb is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Anas ibn Mālik.]
He is Anas ibn Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him, the Companion of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and his servant, and one of the seven known for abundant narration from the Prophet ﷺ.
This chain is four-linked: Qatādah and ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz are in one rank, so it is a four-linked chain, and it is among the highest chains with Abu Dawud.

P6715 - Explanation of Sunan Abi Dawud [237]
The Sacred Law has made clear that what becomes unlawful due to suckling is the same as what becomes unlawful due to lineage, and that the rulings of suckling are like the rulings of lineage: the wet-nurse becomes a mother to the suckling child, her husband—who is the owner of the milk—becomes a father to the child, her children become siblings to the child, and in this manner the prohibition of marriage spreads through ascendants and descendants.

حدثنا إبراهيم بن محمد التيمي حدثنا يحيى عن عبيد الله بن الأخنس عن عمرو بن شعيب عن أبيه عن جده رضي الله عنه أن مرثد بن أبي مرثد الغنوي كان يحمل الأسارى بمكة، وكان بمكة بغي يقال لها: عناق، وكانت صديقته، قال: (جئت إلى النبي صلى الله عليه وآله وسلم فقلت: يا رسول الله! أنكح عناقاً؟ قال: فسكت عني، فنزلت: {وَالزَّانِيَةُ لا يَنكِحُهَا إِلَّا زَانٍ أَوْ مُشْرِكٌ} [النور: ٣]، فدعاني فقرأها علي وقال: لا تنكحها)].
قال الإمام أبو داود السجستاني رحمه الله تعالى: [باب في قوله تعالى: {وَالزَّانِيَةُ لا يَنكِحُهَا إِلَّا زَانٍ أَوْ مُشْرِكٌ} [النور: ٣]].
هذه الآية الكريمة تدل على أن الزاني لا ينكح إلا زانية أو مشركة، والزانية لا ينكحها إلا زان أو مشرك، وقد ذكر أبو داود هذه الترجمة وأورد هذا الحديث تحتها لبيان أن الزواج بالزانية لا يجوز؛ لنهي النبي صلى الله عليه وسلم عنه.

P6706 - حكم الزواج بالزانية وأقوال العلماء فيه
وقد اختلف العلماء في حكم الزواج بالزانية: فمنهم من قال: إنه يجوز أن يتزوج العفيف بالزانية؛ لأنها من جملة إماء المسلمين وجملة الأيامى اللاتي قال الله تعالى فيهن: {وَأَنكِحُوا الأَيَامَى مِنْكُمْ} [النور: ٣٢]، فيدخل في ذلك الزواني وغير الزواني.
وقال بعض أهل العلم: إن العفيف لا ينكح الزانية، وإنما ينكحها زانٍ مثلها، وقد جاء في الحديث الذي بعد هذا: (لا ينكح الزاني المجلود إلا مثله)، فمعناه إذاً أن العفيف لا يتزوج الزانية، وأن الزاني له أن يتزوج الزانية؛ لأن اشتغالهما بالحلال خير من اشتغالهما بالحرام.
ومن العلماء من قال: إن هذه الآية الكريمة ليست في الزواج وإنما هي في الوطء، والمقصود بها أن الزاني لا يطأ زانية أو مشركة، أي: لا يزني إلا بزانية أو مشركة، فالمراد بالنكاح هنا الوطء؛ لأن الله قال: «إِلَّا زَانٍ أَوْ مُشْرِكٌ» قالوا: فقد جاء ذكر المشرك، والمشرك لا يمكن بحال أن يعقد على مسلمة، فلا يجوز للمشرك أن يتزوج مسلمة ولا يجوز للمسلمة أن ينكحها مشرك، فقالوا: فالنكاح هنا يراد به الوطء، وعلى هذا فالزاني لا يطأ إلا زانية، يعني: فاجرة مثله، أو مشركة

P6709 - تراجم رجال إسناد حديث (لا ينكح الزاني المجلود إلا مثله)
قوله: [قال: حدثنا مسدد].
هو مسدد بن مسرهد، وهو ثقة، أخرج له البخاري وأبو داود والترمذي والنسائي.
[وأبو معمر].
هو عبد الله بن عمرو بن أبي الحجاج، وهو ثقة، أخرج له أصحاب الكتب الستة.
[حدثنا عبد الوارث].
هو عبد الوارث بن سعيد العنبري، وهو ثقة، أخرج له أصحاب الكتب الستة.
[عن حبيب].
هو حبيب المعلم، وهو صدوق، أخرج له أصحاب الكتب الستة.
[عن عمرو بن شعيب عن سعيد المقبري].
عمرو بن شعيب قد مر ذكره، وسعيد المقبري ثقة أخرج له أصحاب الكتب الستة.
[عن أبي هريرة].
هو عبد الرحمن بن صخر الدوسي صاحب رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم، وأكثر أصحابه حديثاً على الإطلاق رضي الله عنه وأرضاه.
[وقال أبو معمر: حدثني حبيب المعلم عن عمرو بن شعيب].
يعني: أن اللفظ الذي ساقه هو على لفظ الشيخ الأول وهو مسدد، ثم أخبر عن الشيخ الثاني، فالرواية عن أبي معمر جاءت بزيادة لفظ (المعلم) إضافة إلى حبيب، وأيضاً الأول بلفظ (عن) وهنا بلفظ التحديث.

قال المصنف رحمه الله تعالى: [باب في الرجل يعتق أمته ثم يتزوجها.
حدثنا هناد بن السري حدثنا عبثر عن مطرف عن عامر عن أبي بردة عن أبي موسى رضي الله عنه أنه قال: قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله وسلم: (من أعتق جاريته وتزوجها كان له أجران)].
أورد أبو داود هذه الترجمة، وهي [باب في الرجل يعتق أمته ويتزوجها] أي: أن ذلك صحيح وفيه أجر عظيم، وذلك أن النبي صلى الله عليه وسلم قال كما في حديث أبي موسى: (كان له أجران) يعني: أجر على عتقه وأجر على إحسانه إليها بالعتق والزواج، حيث تزوجها وصار لها حق القسم بعد أن كانت لا قسم لها، فأحسن إليها بأن نقلها من حالة أنه لا قسم لها إلى حالة أنها من جملة الزوجات اللاتي يقسم لهن، فيكون له أجران: أجر على إعتاقه وإحسانه إليها بالعتق، وأجر على إحسانه إليها بالزواج، وكونها صارت من جملة زوجاته اللاتي لهن حق القسمة.

P6712 - تراجم رجال إسناد حديث (من أعتق جاريته ثم تزوجها كان له أجران)

[عن أبي بردة].
هو أبو بردة بن أبي موسى الأشعري، وهو ثقة، أخرج له أصحاب الكتب الستة.

هو أبو موسى الأشعري عبد الله بن قيس رضي الله تعالى عنه، وحديثه أخرجه أصحاب الكتب الستة، فكل رجال هذا الإسناد أخرج لهم أصحاب الكتب الستة إلا هناداً فلم يخرج له البخاري في الصحيح، وإنما خرج له في (خلق أفعال العباد).

P6713 - شرح حديث إعتاق النبي صلى الله عليه وسلم صفية وجعله عتقها صداقها
قال المصنف رحمه الله تعالى: [حدثنا عمرو بن عون أخبرنا أبو عوانة عن قتادة وعبد العزيز بن صهيب عن أنس بن مالك رضي الله عنه (أن النبي صلى الله عليه وآله وسلم أعتق صفية رضي الله عنها، وجعل عتقها صداقها)].
أورد أبو داود حديث أنس بن مالك رضي الله عنه أن النبي صلى الله عليه وسلم تزوج صفية وجعل عتقها صداقها، وصفية هي بنت حيي بن أخطب رضي الله عنها أم المؤمنين، وقد كانت أمة فاعتقها، فالنبي صلى الله عليه وسلم وجعل عتقها صداقها، فدل ذلك على ما ترجم له المصنف من الإعتاق والزواج، وأنه يكون قد أحسن بذلك إحسانين، وأنه يجوز أن يجعل العتق صداقاً؛ لأنه نعمة أنعم بها عليها، وقد اختلف العلماء في ذلك هل هو خاص بالرسول صلى الله عليه وسلم أم أنه له ولغيره، والقول بالخصوصية يحتاج إلى دليل، فالصحيح أن ذلك سائغ وجائز، وأنه ليس من خصائص الرسول صلى الله عليه وسلم.
قوله: (أعتق صفية وجعل عتقها صداقها).
يعني: أعتقها وتزوجها، وعتقها هو صداقها.

P6714 - تراجم رجال إسناد حديث إعتاق النبي صلى الله عليه وسلم صفية وجعله عتقها صداقها
قوله: [حدثنا عمرو بن عون].
عمرو بن عون ثقة، أخرج له أصحاب الكتب الستة.
[أخبرنا أبو عوانة].
هو الوضاح بن عبد الله اليشكري، هو ثقة، أخرج له أصحاب الكتب الستة.
[عن قتادة].
هو قتادة بن دعامة السدوسي البصري، وهو ثقة، أخرج له أصحاب الكتب الستة.
[وعبد العزيز بن صهيب].
عبد العزيز بن صهيب ثقة، أخرج له أصحاب الكتب الستة.
[عن أنس بن مالك].
هو أنس بن مالك رضي الله عنه صاحب رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم وخادمه، وأحد السبعة المعروفين بكثرة الحديث عن النبي صلى الله عليه وسلم.
وهذا الإسناد رباعي، فـ قتادة وعبد العزيز في درجة واحدة، فهو إسناد رباعي، وهو من أعلى الأسانيد عند أبي داود.

Translating and formatting hadith text
translation = """P6704 - Allah the Exalted’s statement: (The fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress or an idolatress)

P6705 - Explanation of the hadith of the Prophet ﷺ forbidding Marthad from marrying the prostitute ʿAnaq
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: Concerning Allah the Exalted’s statement: {The fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress} (al-Nur: 3).
Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī narrated to us; Yaḥyā narrated to us, from ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas, from ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb, from his father, from his grandfather, may Allah be pleased with him, that Marthad ibn Abi Marthad al-Ghanawi used to carry captives in Makkah. In Makkah there was a prostitute called ʿAnaq, and she had been his friend. He said: (I came to the Prophet ﷺ and said: O Messenger of Allah! Shall I marry ʿAnaq? He remained silent toward me. Then it was revealed: {And the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater} (al-Nur: 3). Then he called me and recited it to me and said: Do not marry her.)].
Imam Abu Dawud al-Sijistani, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: Concerning Allah the Exalted’s statement: {And the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater} (al-Nur: 3).]
This noble verse indicates that the fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress or an idolatress, and the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater. Abu Dawud mentioned this chapter heading and cited this hadith under it to make clear that marriage to a fornicatress is not permissible, due to the Prophet’s ﷺ prohibition of it.

P6706 - The ruling on marrying a fornicatress and the statements of the scholars concerning it
The scholars have differed regarding the ruling of marrying a fornicatress. Some of them said that it is permissible for a chaste man to marry a fornicatress, because she is among the slave-women of the Muslims and among the unmarried women about whom Allah the Exalted said: {Marry off the unmarried among you} (al-Nur: 32); so that includes fornicatresses and others besides fornicatresses.
Some of the people of knowledge said that the chaste man does not marry the fornicatress; rather, a fornicator like her marries her. In the hadith that comes after this there occurs: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him). Its meaning, then, is that the chaste man does not marry the fornicatress, and that the fornicator may marry the fornicatress, because their occupying themselves with what is lawful is better than their occupying themselves with what is unlawful.
Among the scholars are those who said that this noble verse is not about marriage; rather, it is about intercourse. Its intent is that the fornicator does not have intercourse with a fornicatress or an idolatress—meaning, he does not commit fornication except with a fornicatress or an idolatress. So “nikah” here is meant as intercourse, because Allah said: “except a fornicator or an idolater.” They said: the idolater has been mentioned, and an idolater can in no case contract marriage to a Muslim woman; it is not permissible for an idolater to marry a Muslim woman, and it is not permissible for a Muslim woman to be married by an idolater. So they said: “nikah” here is meant as intercourse. On this basis, the fornicator does not have intercourse except with a fornicatress—meaning, an immoral woman like him—or an idolatress who does not acknowledge what is lawful or unlawful. Likewise, the reverse: “And the fornicatress is not ‘nikah-ed’ except by a fornicator” like her “or an idolater” who does not distinguish between lawful and unlawful and deems fornication permissible.
They said: so mentioning the idolater here indicates that what is meant is intercourse.
But the hadith the author cited here regarding the reason for the revelation of the verse—that the Messenger ﷺ recited it to him and said: (Do not marry her)—indicates that what is meant is marriage.
Our shaykh, Shaykh Muhammad al-Amin al-Shinqiti, may Allah have mercy on him, spoke about this verse in Adwa’ al-Bayan and said: this is among the most difficult issues, because the contextual indicator in the verse shows that what is meant by “nikah” is intercourse, while the reason for revelation shows that what is meant by “nikah” is marriage. He said: escaping—meaning, from this difficulty—is hard, and it is not achieved except with a kind of strain and contrivance. Then he pointed to something of that and said: “nikah” is taken as a shared word between the two meanings: it is used for intercourse and it is used for marriage; so what is meant is marriage in one respect and intercourse in another respect.
The meaning of that is that if what is intended by it is intercourse in fornication, that is due to the indication of mentioning the idolater; so what is intended is intercourse because of the contextual indicator of mentioning the idolater. And the hadith in which the Prophet ﷺ forbade him to marry her indicates that what is intended is marriage. Thus the verse is explained by both meanings and carried on both meanings that the wording indicates by shared usage: intercourse and marriage.
The upshot is that marriage to a fornicatress by a chaste man is not permissible, as the hadith indicates. As for the marriage of a fornicator to a fornicatress, it is allowable, due to his ﷺ statement: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him) in the forthcoming hadith. His statement: “flogged” means that his fornication has become apparent and established by the presence of flogging for it; so the fornicator whose fornication has been established does not marry except one like him.
What appears is that the chaste man does not marry the immoral fornicatress; as for the fornicator, he marries her instead of the two of them occupying themselves with what is unlawful.
As for the hadith, it contains that Marthad ibn Abi Marthad al-Ghanawi came to the Prophet ﷺ, and he used to carry captives from Makkah to Madinah. There was in Makkah a prostitute called ʿAnaq, and she had been his companion. He sought the Prophet’s ﷺ permission to marry her, so he recited the verse to him and said to him: (Do not marry her). This indicates that it is not permissible for the chaste man to marry the fornicatress, and that the fornicator may marry the fornicatress who is like him. As for the idolater, it is not permissible for him to marry a Muslim woman at all, due to the texts of the Book and the Sunnah regarding that.
What is meant by the chaste man not marrying the fornicatress is before her repentance. As for when she repents, then repentance wipes out what came before it, and Allah the Exalted accepts repentance from whoever repents; and the chaste man may marry her.

P6707 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the hadith of the Prophet ﷺ forbidding Marthad from marrying the prostitute ʿAnaq
His statement: [Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī narrated to us.]
Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī is trustworthy; Abu Dawud and al-Nasa’i narrated from him.
[Yaḥyā narrated to us.]
He is Yaḥyā ibn Saʿīd al-Qaṭṭān, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas.]
ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas is truthful; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb.]
He is ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb ibn Muḥammad ibn ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿAmr ibn al-ʿĀṣ, and he is truthful. Al-Bukhari narrated from him in (Juz’ al-Qira’ah) and the authors of the Sunan.
[From his father.]
He is Shuʿayb, and he is truthful. Al-Bukhari narrated from him in (Juz’ al-Qira’ah) and (al-Adab al-Mufrad), and the authors of the Sunan.
[From his grandfather.]
He is Shuʿayb’s grandfather, and he is ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿAmr ibn al-ʿĀṣ, may Allah be pleased with them both, the noble Companion, one of the four Abd Allahs among the Companions of the Prophet ﷺ. The authors of the Six Books narrated his hadith.

P6708 - Explanation of the hadith: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him)
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Musaddad and Abū Muʿammar said: ʿAbd al-Wārith narrated to us, from Ḥabīb—ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb narrated to me—from Saʿīd al-Maqburī, from Abū Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him).]
Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Abū Hurayrah: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him). This indicates that the fornicator marries the fornicatress, and that is when both are not repentant. As for when they have repented, then repentance wipes out what came before it; the chaste man may marry the fornicatress if she repents, and likewise the reverse.
His statement: “flogged” means: the one upon whom the legal punishment has been carried out and whose fornication has been established. It has no contrary implication in the sense that the one who was not flogged would not be like that; rather, he is the same. The flogged and the non-flogged are equal in that regard. It only mentioned “flogged” because through it the existence of fornication is established. Flogging is an expiation for him; but if he does not repent, it is only an expiation for the sin that occurred from him. As for if he persists, then the flogging does not expiate his persistence, and he is not married to a chaste woman. However, if it happens that a fornicator has a marriage contract conducted for him with a chaste woman, then the contract is valid, and it is not said that the contract is invalid, even though he is not a suitable match for her.
As for the chaste man, many scholars permitted him to marry the fornicatress, using as evidence Allah the Exalted’s statement: {Marry off the unmarried among you} (al-Nur: 32).

P6709 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the hadith: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him)
His statement: [He said: Musaddad narrated to us.]
He is Musaddad ibn Musarhad, trustworthy; al-Bukhari, Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and al-Nasa’i narrated from him.
[And Abū Muʿammar.]
He is ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿAmr ibn Abī al-Ḥajjāj, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[ʿAbd al-Wārith narrated to us.]
He is ʿAbd al-Wārith ibn Saʿīd al-ʿAnbarī, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Ḥabīb.]
He is Ḥabīb al-Muʿallim, truthful; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb, from Saʿīd al-Maqburī.]
ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb has already been mentioned, and Saʿīd al-Maqburī is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Abū Hurayrah.]
He is ʿAbd al-Raḥmān ibn Ṣakhr al-Dawsī, the Companion of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and the most prolific of his Companions in hadith without exception—may Allah be pleased with him and grant him pleasure.
[And Abū Muʿammar said: Ḥabīb al-Muʿallim narrated to me, from ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb.]
Meaning: the wording he cited is upon the wording of the first shaykh, Musaddad, then he informed about the second shaykh. The narration from Abū Muʿammar came with the additional word “al-Muʿallim” appended to Ḥabīb; also, the first came with the wording “from,” whereas here it is with the wording of direct narration.

P6710 - A man frees his slave-girl, then marries her

P6711 - Explanation of the hadith: (Whoever frees his slave-girl, then marries her, has two rewards)
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: A man frees his slave-girl, then marries her.
Hannād ibn al-Sarī narrated to us; ʿAbthar narrated to us, from Muṭarrif, from ʿĀmir, from Abū Burdah, from Abū Mūsā, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (Whoever frees his slave-girl and marries her has two rewards).]
Abu Dawud cited this chapter heading—[Chapter: A man frees his slave-girl and marries her]—meaning: that this is valid and that it contains tremendous reward. That is because the Prophet ﷺ said, as in the hadith of Abū Mūsā: (He has two rewards), meaning: a reward for emancipating her and a reward for his kindness to her through emancipation and marriage. He married her, and she came to have a right to an allotted turn after previously having no allotted turn; he treated her well by transferring her from a state in which she had no allotted turn to a state in which she is among the wives who receive allotted turns. Thus he has two rewards: a reward for emancipating her and treating her well through emancipation, and a reward for treating her well through marriage, and for her becoming among his wives who have a right to an allotted turn.

P6712 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the hadith: (Whoever frees his slave-girl, then marries her, has two rewards)

P6713 - Explanation of the hadith of the Prophet ﷺ emancipating Safiyyah and making her emancipation her dower
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [ʿAmr ibn ʿAwn narrated to us; Abū ʿAwānah informed us, from Qatādah and ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz ibn Ṣuhayb, from Anas ibn Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him: (that the Prophet ﷺ emancipated Safiyyah, may Allah be pleased with her, and made her emancipation her dower).]
Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Anas ibn Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet ﷺ married Safiyyah and made her emancipation her dower. Safiyyah is the daughter of Huyayy ibn Akhtab, may Allah be pleased with her, the Mother of the Believers. She had been a slave-girl, so he emancipated her, and the Prophet ﷺ made her emancipation her dower. This indicates what the author wrote the chapter heading for: emancipation and marriage, and that by doing so he has shown two kinds of kindness, and that it is permissible to make emancipation a dower, because it is a blessing he bestowed upon her. The scholars have differed regarding whether this is specific to the Messenger ﷺ or whether it is for him and others besides him. Saying that it is specific requires evidence; the correct view is that it is allowable and permissible, and that it is not among the special characteristics of the Messenger ﷺ.
His statement: (He emancipated Safiyyah and made her emancipation her dower) means: he emancipated her and married her, and her emancipation is her dower.

P6715 - Explanation of Sunan Abu Dawud [237]
The Sacred Law has made clear that what becomes unlawful due to suckling is the same as what becomes unlawful due to lineage, and that the rulings of suckling are like the rulings of lineage: the wet-nurse becomes a mother to the suckling child, her husband—who is the owner of the milk—becomes a father to the child, her children become siblings to the child, and in this manner the prohibition of marriage spreads through ascendants and descendants.

translation = """P6704 - Allah the Exalted’s statement: (The fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress or an idolatress)

P6705 - Explanation of the hadith of the Prophet ﷺ forbidding Marthad from marrying the prostitute Anaq
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: Concerning Allah the Exalted’s statement: {The fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress} (al-Nur: 3).
Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī narrated to us; Yaḥyā narrated to us, from ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas, from ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb, from his father, from his grandfather, may Allah be pleased with him, that Marthad ibn Abi Marthad al-Ghanawi used to carry captives in Makkah. In Makkah there was a prostitute called Anaq, and she had been his companion. He said: (I came to the Prophet ﷺ and said: O Messenger of Allah! Shall I marry Anaq? He remained silent toward me. Then it was revealed: {And the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater} (al-Nur: 3). Then he called me, recited it to me, and said: Do not marry her.)].
Imam Abu Dawud al-Sijistani, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: Concerning Allah the Exalted’s statement: {And the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater} (al-Nur: 3).]
This noble verse indicates that the fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress or an idolatress, and the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater. Abu Dawud mentioned this chapter heading and cited this hadith under it to make clear that marriage to a fornicatress is not permissible, due to the Prophet’s ﷺ prohibition of it.

P6706 - The ruling on marrying a fornicatress and the statements of the scholars concerning it
The scholars have differed regarding the ruling of marrying a fornicatress. Some of them said that it is permissible for a chaste man to marry a fornicatress, because she is among the slave-women of the Muslims and among the unmarried women about whom Allah the Exalted said: {Marry off the unmarried among you} (al-Nur: 32); so that includes fornicatresses and others besides fornicatresses.
Some of the people of knowledge said that the chaste man does not marry the fornicatress; rather, a fornicator like her marries her. In the hadith that comes after this there occurs: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him). Its meaning, then, is that the chaste man does not marry the fornicatress, and that the fornicator may marry the fornicatress, because their occupying themselves with what is lawful is better than their occupying themselves with what is unlawful.
Among the scholars are those who said that this noble verse is not about marriage; rather, it is about intercourse. Its intent is that the fornicator does not have intercourse with a fornicatress or an idolatress—meaning, he does not commit fornication except with a fornicatress or an idolatress. So “nikah” here is meant as intercourse, because Allah said: “except a fornicator or an idolater.” They said: the idolater has been mentioned, and an idolater can in no case contract marriage to a Muslim woman; thus it is not permissible for an idolater to marry a Muslim woman, and it is not permissible for a Muslim woman to be married by an idolater. So they said: “nikah” here is intended as intercourse. On this basis, the fornicator does not have intercourse except with a fornicatress—meaning, one immoral like him—or with an idolatress who does not acknowledge what is lawful and unlawful. Likewise the reverse: “And the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator”—one like her—“or an idolater,” who does not distinguish between what is lawful and unlawful and considers fornication permissible.
They said: so mentioning the idolater here indicates that what is meant is intercourse.
But the hadith the author cited here regarding the reason for the revelation of the verse—that the Messenger ﷺ recited it to him and said: (Do not marry her)—indicates that what is meant is marriage.
Our shaykh, Shaykh Muhammad al-Amin al-Shinqiti, may Allah have mercy on him, spoke about this verse in (Adwa’ al-Bayan) and said: this is among the most difficult issues, because the contextual indicator in the verse shows that what is meant by “nikah” is intercourse, while the reason for revelation shows that what is meant by “nikah” is marriage. He said: escaping—meaning, from this difficulty—is hard and is not achieved except with a kind of strain and contrivance. Then he pointed to something of that and said: “nikah” is taken as a word shared between the two meanings: it is used for intercourse and it is used for marriage. Thus what is meant is marriage in one respect and intercourse in another respect.
The meaning of that is that if what is intended by it is intercourse in fornication, that is due to the indication of mentioning the idolater; so what is intended is intercourse because of the contextual indicator of mentioning the idolater. And the hadith in which the Prophet ﷺ forbade him to marry her indicates that what is intended is marriage. Thus the verse is explained by both meanings and carried on both meanings that the wording indicates by shared usage: intercourse and marriage.
The upshot is that marriage to a fornicatress by a chaste man is not permissible, as the hadith indicates. As for the marriage of a fornicator to a fornicatress, it is allowable, due to his ﷺ statement: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him) in the forthcoming hadith. His statement: “flogged” means that his fornication has become apparent and established by the presence of flogging for it; so the fornicator whose fornication has been established does not marry except one like him.
What appears is that the chaste man does not marry the immoral fornicatress; as for the fornicator, he marries her instead of the two of them occupying themselves with what is unlawful.
As for the hadith, it contains that Marthad ibn Abi Marthad al-Ghanawi came to the Prophet ﷺ, and he used to carry captives from Makkah to Madinah. There was in Makkah a prostitute called Anaq, and she had been his companion. He sought the Prophet’s ﷺ permission to marry her, so he recited the verse to him and said to him: (Do not marry her). This indicates that it is not permissible for the chaste man to marry the fornicatress, and that the fornicator may marry the fornicatress who is like him. As for the idolater, it is not permissible for him to marry a Muslim woman at all, due to what has come in the texts of the Book and the Sunnah concerning that.
What is meant by the chaste man not marrying the fornicatress is before her repentance. As for when she repents, then repentance wipes out what came before it, and Allah the Exalted accepts repentance from whoever repents; and the chaste man may marry her.

P6707 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the hadith of the Prophet ﷺ forbidding Marthad from marrying the prostitute Anaq
His statement: [Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī narrated to us.]
Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī is trustworthy; Abu Dawud and al-Nasa'i narrated from him.
[Yaḥyā narrated to us.]
He is Yaḥyā ibn Saʿīd al-Qaṭṭān, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas.]
ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas is truthful; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb.]
He is ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb ibn Muḥammad ibn ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿAmr ibn al-ʿĀṣ, and he is truthful. Al-Bukhari narrated from him in (Juz' al-Qira'ah), and the authors of the Sunan.
[From his father.]
He is Shuʿayb, and he is truthful. Al-Bukhari narrated from him in (Juz' al-Qira'ah) and (al-Adab al-Mufrad), and the authors of the Sunan.
[From his grandfather.]
He is Shuʿayb’s grandfather, and he is ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿAmr ibn al-ʿĀṣ, may Allah be pleased with them both, the noble Companion, one of the four Abd Allahs among the Companions of the Prophet ﷺ. The authors of the Six Books narrated his hadith.

P6708 - Explanation of the hadith: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him)
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Musaddad and Abū Muʿammar said: ʿAbd al-Wārith narrated to us, from Ḥabīb, who narrated to me: ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb, from Saʿīd al-Maqburī, from Abū Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him).]
Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Abū Hurayrah: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him). This indicates that the fornicator marries the fornicatress, and that is when both are not repentant. As for when they have repented, then repentance wipes out what came before it; the chaste man may marry the fornicatress if she repents, and likewise the reverse.
His statement: “flogged” means: the one upon whom the legal punishment has been carried out and whose fornication has been established. It has no contrary implication in the sense that the one who was not flogged would not be like that; rather, he is the same. The flogged and the non-flogged are equal in that regard, but it mentioned “flogged” because through it the existence of fornication is established. Flogging is an expiation for him; but if he does not repent, it is an expiation for the sin that occurred from him only. As for if he persists, then the flogging does not expiate his persistence, and he is not married to a chaste woman. However, if it happens that a fornicator is contracted in marriage to a chaste woman, the contract is valid and it is not said that the contract is void, even if he is not a suitable match for her.
As for the chaste man, many scholars permitted him to marry the fornicatress, using as evidence Allah the Exalted’s statement: {Marry off the unmarried among you} (al-Nur: 32).

P6709 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the hadith: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him)
His statement: [He said: Musaddad narrated to us.]

[From Abū Hurayrah.]
He is ʿAbd al-Raḥmān ibn Ṣakhr al-Dawsī, the Companion of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and the most prolific of his Companions in hadith without exception—may Allah be pleased with him and grant him pleasure.
[And Abū Muʿammar said: Ḥabīb al-Muʿallim narrated to me, from ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb.]
Meaning: the wording he cited is upon the wording of the first shaykh, Musaddad; then he informed about the second shaykh. The narration from Abū Muʿammar came with the additional word “al-Muʿallim” appended to Ḥabīb; also, the first was with the wording “from,” while here it is with the wording of direct narration.

P6710 - A man frees his slave-girl, then marries her

P6711 - Explanation of the hadith: (Whoever frees his slave-girl, then marries her, has two rewards)
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: A man frees his slave-girl, then marries her.
Hannād ibn al-Sarī narrated to us; ʿAbthar narrated to us, from Muṭarrif, from ʿĀmir, from Abū Burdah, from Abū Mūsā, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (Whoever frees his slave-girl and marries her has two rewards).]
Abu Dawud cited this chapter heading—[Chapter: A man frees his slave-girl and marries her]—meaning: that this is valid and that it contains tremendous reward. That is because the Prophet ﷺ said, as in the hadith of Abū Mūsā: (He has two rewards), meaning: a reward for emancipating her and a reward for his kindness to her through emancipation and marriage. He married her, and she came to have a right to an allotted turn after previously having no allotted turn. Thus he treated her well by transferring her from the state of having no allotted turn to the state of being among the wives for whom turns are allotted. So he has two rewards: a reward for emancipating her and being kind to her through emancipation, and a reward for being kind to her through marriage, and for her becoming among his wives who have the right to an allotted turn.

translation = """P6704 - Allah the Exalted’s statement: (The fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress or an idolatress)

P6705 - Explanation of the hadith of the Prophet ﷺ forbidding Marthad from marrying the prostitute Anaq
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: Concerning Allah the Exalted’s statement: {The fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress} (al-Nur: 3).
Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī narrated to us; Yaḥyā narrated to us, from ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas, from ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb, from his father, from his grandfather, may Allah be pleased with him, that Marthad ibn Abi Marthad al-Ghanawi used to carry captives in Makkah. In Makkah there was a prostitute called Anaq, and she had been his companion. He said: (I came to the Prophet ﷺ and said: O Messenger of Allah! Shall I marry Anaq? He remained silent toward me. Then it was revealed: {And the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater} (al-Nur: 3). Then he called me, recited it to me, and said: Do not marry her.)]
Imam Abu Dawud al-Sijistani, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: Concerning Allah the Exalted’s statement: {And the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater} (al-Nur: 3).]
This noble verse indicates that the fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress or an idolatress, and the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater. Abu Dawud mentioned this chapter heading and cited this hadith under it to make clear that marriage to a fornicatress is not permissible, due to the Prophet’s ﷺ prohibition of it.

P6706 - The ruling on marrying a fornicatress and the statements of the scholars concerning it
The scholars have differed regarding the ruling of marrying a fornicatress. Some of them said that it is permissible for a chaste man to marry a fornicatress, because she is among the slave-women of the Muslims and among the unmarried women about whom Allah the Exalted said: {Marry off the unmarried among you} (al-Nur: 32); so that includes fornicatresses and others besides fornicatresses.
Some of the people of knowledge said that the chaste man does not marry the fornicatress; rather, a fornicator like her marries her. In the hadith that comes after this there occurs: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him). Its meaning, then, is that the chaste man does not marry the fornicatress, and that the fornicator may marry the fornicatress, because their occupying themselves with what is lawful is better than their occupying themselves with what is unlawful.
Among the scholars are those who said that this noble verse is not about marriage; rather, it is about intercourse. Its intent is that the fornicator does not have intercourse with a fornicatress or an idolatress—meaning, he does not commit fornication except with a fornicatress or an idolatress. So “nikah” here is meant as intercourse, because Allah said: “except a fornicator or an idolater.” They said: the idolater has been mentioned, and an idolater can in no case contract marriage to a Muslim woman; so it is not permissible for an idolater to marry a Muslim woman, nor is it permissible for a Muslim woman to be married by an idolater. So they said: “nikah” here is intended as intercourse. On that basis, the fornicator does not have intercourse except with a fornicatress—meaning, an immoral woman like him—or with an idolatress who does not acknowledge what is lawful or unlawful. Likewise, the reverse: “And the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator,” one like her, “or an idolater,” who does not distinguish between the lawful and the unlawful and deems fornication permissible.
They said: so mentioning the idolater here indicates that what is meant is intercourse.
But the hadith the author cited here regarding the reason for the revelation of the verse—that the Messenger ﷺ recited it to him and said: (Do not marry her)—indicates that what is meant is marriage.
Our shaykh, Shaykh Muhammad al-Amin al-Shinqiti, may Allah have mercy on him, spoke about this verse in (Adwa’ al-Bayan) and said: this is among the most difficult issues, because the contextual indicator in the verse shows that what is meant by “nikah” is intercourse, while the reason for revelation shows that what is meant by “nikah” is marriage. He said: escaping—meaning, from this difficulty—is hard and is not achieved except with a kind of strain and contrivance. Then he pointed to something of that and said: “nikah” is taken as a shared term for the two meanings: it is used for intercourse and it is used for marriage; so what is intended by it is marriage in one respect and intercourse in another respect.
The meaning of that is that if what is intended by it is intercourse in fornication, that is due to the indication of mentioning the idolater; so what is intended is intercourse because of the contextual indicator of mentioning the idolater. And the hadith in which the Prophet ﷺ forbade him to marry her indicates that what is intended is marriage. Thus the verse is explained by both meanings and carried on both meanings that the wording indicates by shared usage: intercourse and marriage.
The upshot is that marriage to a fornicatress by a chaste man is not permissible, as the hadith indicates. As for the marriage of a fornicator to a fornicatress, it is allowable, due to his ﷺ statement: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him) in the forthcoming hadith. His statement: “flogged” means that his fornication has become apparent and established by the presence of flogging for it; so the fornicator whose fornication has been established does not marry except one like him.
What appears is that the chaste man does not marry the immoral fornicatress; as for the fornicator, he marries her instead of the two of them occupying themselves with what is unlawful.
As for the hadith, it contains that Marthad ibn Abi Marthad al-Ghanawi came to the Prophet ﷺ, and he used to carry captives from Makkah to Madinah. There was in Makkah a prostitute called Anaq, and she had been his companion. He sought the Prophet’s ﷺ permission to marry her, so he recited the verse to him and said to him: (Do not marry her). This indicates that it is not permissible for the chaste man to marry the fornicatress, and that the fornicator may marry the fornicatress who is like him. As for the idolater, it is not permissible for him to marry a Muslim woman at all, due to the texts of the Book and the Sunnah that have come concerning that.
What is meant by the chaste man not marrying the fornicatress is before her repentance. As for when she repents, then repentance wipes out what came before it, and Allah the Exalted accepts repentance from whoever repents; and the chaste man may marry her.

P6708 - Explanation of the hadith: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him)
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Musaddad and Abū Muʿammar said: ʿAbd al-Wārith narrated to us, from Ḥabīb; ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb narrated to me, from Saʿīd al-Maqburī, from Abū Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him).]
Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Abū Hurayrah: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him). This indicates that the fornicator marries the fornicatress, and that is when both are not repentant. As for when they have repented, then repentance wipes out what came before it; the chaste man may marry the fornicatress if she repents, and likewise the reverse.
His statement: “flogged” means: the one upon whom the legal punishment has been carried out and whose fornication has been established. It has no contrary implication in the sense that the one who was not flogged would not be like that; rather, he is the same. The flogged and the non-flogged are equal in that regard; it mentioned “flogged” because through it the existence of fornication is established. Flogging is an expiation for him; but if he does not repent, it is an expiation for the sin that occurred from him only. As for if he persists, the flogging does not expiate his persistence, and he is not married to a chaste woman. However, if it happens that a fornicator has a marriage contract concluded for him with a chaste woman, then the contract is valid, and it is not said: the contract is void, even if he is not a suitable match for her.
As for the chaste man, many scholars permitted him to marry the fornicatress, using as evidence Allah the Exalted’s statement: {Marry off the unmarried among you} (al-Nur: 32).

P6709 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the hadith: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him)
His statement: [He said: Musaddad narrated to us.]
He is Musaddad ibn Musarhad, and he is trustworthy; al-Bukhari, Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and al-Nasa'i narrated from him.
[And Abū Muʿammar.]
He is ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿAmr ibn Abī al-Ḥajjāj, and he is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[ʿAbd al-Wārith narrated to us.]
He is ʿAbd al-Wārith ibn Saʿīd al-ʿAnbarī, and he is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Ḥabīb.]
He is Ḥabīb al-Muʿallim, and he is truthful; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb, from Saʿīd al-Maqburī.]
ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb has already been mentioned, and Saʿīd al-Maqburī is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Abū Hurayrah.]
He is ʿAbd al-Raḥmān ibn Ṣakhr al-Dawsī, the Companion of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and the most prolific of his Companions in hadith without exception—may Allah be pleased with him and grant him pleasure.
[And Abū Muʿammar said: Ḥabīb al-Muʿallim narrated to me, from ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb.]
Meaning: the wording he cited is upon the wording of the first shaykh, Musaddad. Then he informed about the second shaykh: the narration from Abū Muʿammar came with the additional word “al-Muʿallim” appended to Ḥabīb; and also the first was with the wording “from,” whereas here it is with the wording of direct narration.

P6710 - A man frees his slave-girl, then marries her

P6711 - Explanation of the hadith: (Whoever frees his slave-girl, then marries her, has two rewards)
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: A man frees his slave-girl, then marries her.
Hannād ibn al-Sarī narrated to us; ʿAbthar narrated to us, from Muṭarrif, from ʿĀmir, from Abū Burdah, from Abū Mūsā, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (Whoever frees his slave-girl and marries her has two rewards).]
Abu Dawud cited this chapter heading—[Chapter: A man frees his slave-girl and marries her]—meaning: that this is valid and that it contains tremendous reward. That is because the Prophet ﷺ said, as in the hadith of Abū Mūsā: (He has two rewards), meaning: a reward for emancipating her and a reward for his kindness to her through emancipation and marriage. He married her, and she came to have a right to an allotted turn after previously having no allotted turn. Thus he treated her well by transferring her from a state in which she had no allotted turn to a state in which she was among the wives who are allotted turns. Therefore he has two rewards: a reward for emancipating her and treating her well by emancipation, and a reward for treating her well by marriage and for her becoming among his wives who have the right to an allotted turn.

P6712 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the hadith: (Whoever frees his slave-girl, then marries her, has two rewards)
His statement: [Hannād ibn al-Sarī narrated to us.]
He is Hannād ibn al-Sarī, Abū al-Sarī, and he is trustworthy. Al-Bukhari narrated his hadith in (Khalq Af'al al-'Ibad), and Muslim and the authors of the Sunan.
[ʿAbthar narrated to us.]
ʿAbthar is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Muṭarrif.]
He is Muṭarrif ibn Ṭarīf, and he is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿĀmir.]
He is ʿĀmir ibn Sharāḥīl al-Shaʿbī, and he is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Abū Burdah.]
He is Abū Burdah ibn Abī Mūsā al-Ashʿarī, and he is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Abū Mūsā.]
He is Abū Mūsā al-Ashʿarī, ʿAbd Allāh ibn Qays, may Allah be pleased with him, and the authors of the Six Books narrated his hadith. Thus, all the men of this chain are narrated from by the authors of the Six Books except for Hannād: al-Bukhari did not narrate from him in the Sahih; rather, he narrated from him in (Khalq Af'al al-'Ibad).

P6713 - Explanation of the hadith of the Prophet ﷺ emancipating Safiyyah and making her emancipation her dower
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [ʿAmr ibn ʿAwn narrated to us; Abū ʿAwānah informed us, from Qatādah and ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz ibn Ṣuhayb, from Anas ibn Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him: (that the Prophet ﷺ emancipated Safiyyah, may Allah be pleased with her, and made her emancipation her dower).]
Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Anas ibn Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet ﷺ married Safiyyah and made her emancipation her dower. Safiyyah is the daughter of Huyayy ibn Akhtab, may Allah be pleased with her, the Mother of the Believers. She had been a slave-girl, so he emancipated her, and the Prophet ﷺ made her emancipation her dower. This indicates what the author wrote the chapter heading for regarding emancipation and marriage: that by doing so he has shown two kindnesses, and that it is permissible to make emancipation a dower, because it is a blessing he bestowed upon her. The scholars have differed regarding whether this is specific to the Messenger ﷺ or whether it is for him and others; saying that it is a special characteristic requires evidence, so the correct view is that it is allowable and permissible, and that it is not among the special characteristics of the Messenger ﷺ.
His statement: (He emancipated Safiyyah and made her emancipation her dower) means: he emancipated her and married her, and her emancipation is her dower.

ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz ibn Ṣuhayb is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Anas ibn Mālik.]
He is Anas ibn Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him, the Companion of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and his servant, and one of the seven known for abundant narration from the Prophet ﷺ.
This chain is four-narrator: Qatādah and ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz are in one rank, so it is a four-narrator chain, and it is among the highest chains with Abu Dawud.

P6715 - Explanation of Sunan Abu Dawud [237]

Rewriting full translation without truncation
translation = """P6704 - Allah the Exalted’s statement: (The fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress or an idolatress)

P6705 - Explanation of the hadith of the Prophet ﷺ forbidding Marthad from marrying the prostitute Anaq
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: Concerning Allah the Exalted’s statement: {The fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress} (al-Nur: 3).
Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī narrated to us; Yaḥyā narrated to us, from ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas, from ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb, from his father, from his grandfather, may Allah be pleased with him, that Marthad ibn Abi Marthad al-Ghanawi used to carry captives in Makkah. In Makkah there was a prostitute called Anaq, and she had been his companion. He said: (I came to the Prophet ﷺ and said: O Messenger of Allah! Shall I marry Anaq? He remained silent toward me. Then it was revealed: {And the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater} (al-Nur: 3). Then he called me, recited it to me, and said: Do not marry her.)]
Imam Abu Dawud al-Sijistani, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: Concerning Allah the Exalted’s statement: {And the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater} (al-Nur: 3).]
This noble verse indicates that the fornicator does not marry except a fornicatress or an idolatress, and the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator or an idolater. Abu Dawud mentioned this chapter heading and cited this hadith under it to make clear that marriage to a fornicatress is not permissible, due to the Prophet’s ﷺ prohibition of it.

P6706 - The ruling on marrying a fornicatress and the statements of the scholars concerning it
The scholars have differed regarding the ruling of marrying a fornicatress. Some of them said that it is permissible for a chaste man to marry a fornicatress, because she is among the slave-women of the Muslims and among the unmarried women about whom Allah the Exalted said: {Marry off the unmarried among you} (al-Nur: 32); so that includes fornicatresses and others besides fornicatresses.
Some of the people of knowledge said that the chaste man does not marry the fornicatress; rather, a fornicator like her marries her. In the hadith that comes after this there occurs: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him). Its meaning, then, is that the chaste man does not marry the fornicatress, and that the fornicator may marry the fornicatress, because their occupying themselves with what is lawful is better than their occupying themselves with what is unlawful.
Among the scholars are those who said that this noble verse is not about marriage; rather, it is about intercourse. Its intent is that the fornicator does not have intercourse with a fornicatress or an idolatress—meaning: he does not commit fornication except with a fornicatress or an idolatress. So “nikah” here is meant as intercourse, because Allah said: “except a fornicator or an idolater.” They said: the idolater has been mentioned, and an idolater can in no case contract marriage to a Muslim woman; it is not permissible for an idolater to marry a Muslim woman, and it is not permissible for a Muslim woman to be married to an idolater. They said: therefore “nikah” here is intended as intercourse, and accordingly the fornicator does not have intercourse except with a fornicatress—meaning: an immoral woman like him—or an idolatress who does not acknowledge what is lawful and what is unlawful. And likewise the reverse: “And the fornicatress is not married except by a fornicator” like her, “or an idolater” who does not distinguish lawful from unlawful and deems fornication permissible.
They said: so mentioning the idolater here indicates that what is meant is intercourse.
But the hadith the author cited here regarding the reason for the revelation of the verse—that the Messenger ﷺ recited it to him and said: (Do not marry her)—indicates that what is meant is marriage.
Our shaykh, Shaykh Muhammad al-Amin al-Shinqiti, may Allah have mercy on him, spoke about this verse in (Adwa' al-Bayan) and said: this is among the most difficult issues, because the contextual indicator in the verse shows that what is meant by “nikah” is intercourse, while the reason for revelation shows that what is meant by “nikah” is marriage. He said: escaping—meaning, from this difficulty—is hard and is not achieved except with a kind of strain and contrivance. Then he pointed to something of that and said: “nikah” is a word shared between the two meanings: it is used for intercourse and for marriage; so it is intended as marriage in one consideration and as intercourse in another.
The meaning of that is that if what is intended by it is intercourse in fornication, that is due to the indication of mentioning the idolater; so what is intended is intercourse because of the contextual indicator of mentioning the idolater. And the hadith in which the Prophet ﷺ forbade him to marry her indicates that what is intended is marriage. Thus the verse is explained by both meanings and carried on both meanings that the wording indicates by shared usage: intercourse and marriage.
The upshot is that marriage to a fornicatress by a chaste man is not permissible, as the hadith indicates. As for the marriage of a fornicator to a fornicatress, it is allowable, due to his ﷺ statement: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him) in the forthcoming hadith. His statement: “flogged” means that his fornication has become apparent and established by the presence of flogging for it; so the fornicator whose fornication has been established does not marry except one like him.
What appears is that the chaste man does not marry the immoral fornicatress; as for the fornicator, he marries her instead of the two of them occupying themselves with what is unlawful.
As for the hadith, it contains that Marthad ibn Abi Marthad al-Ghanawi came to the Prophet ﷺ, and he used to carry captives from Makkah to Madinah. There was in Makkah a prostitute called Anaq, and she had been his companion. He sought the Prophet’s ﷺ permission to marry her, so he recited the verse to him and said to him: (Do not marry her). This indicates that it is not permissible for the chaste man to marry the fornicatress, and that the fornicator may marry the fornicatress who is like him. As for the idolater, it is not permissible for him to marry a Muslim woman at all, due to the texts of the Book and the Sunnah regarding that.
What is meant by the chaste man not marrying the fornicatress is before her repentance. As for when she repents, then repentance wipes out what came before it, and Allah the Exalted accepts repentance from whoever repents; and the chaste man may marry her.

P6707 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the hadith of the Prophet ﷺ forbidding Marthad from marrying the prostitute Anaq
His statement: [Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī narrated to us.]
Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Taymī is trustworthy; Abu Dawud and al-Nasa'i narrated from him.
[Yaḥyā narrated to us.]
He is Yaḥyā ibn Saʿīd al-Qaṭṭān, trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas.]
ʿUbayd Allāh ibn al-Akhnas is truthful; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.

He is ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb ibn Muḥammad ibn ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿAmr ibn al-ʿĀṣ, and he is truthful. Al-Bukhari narrated from him in (Juz' al-Qira'ah) and the authors of the Sunan.
[From his father.]
He is Shuʿayb, and he is truthful. Al-Bukhari narrated from him in (Juz' al-Qira'ah) and (al-Adab al-Mufrad), and the authors of the Sunan.

P6708 - Explanation of the hadith: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him)
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Musaddad and Abū Muʿammar said: ʿAbd al-Wārith narrated to us, from Ḥabīb, who narrated to me: ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb, from Saʿīd al-Maqburī, from Abū Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him).]
Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Abū Hurayrah: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him). This indicates that the fornicator marries the fornicatress, and that is when both are not repentant. As for when they have repented, then repentance wipes out what came before it; the chaste man may marry the fornicatress if she repents, and likewise the reverse.
His statement: “flogged” means: the one upon whom the legal punishment has been carried out and whose fornication has been established. It has no contrary implication in the sense that the one who was not flogged would not be like that; rather, he is the same. The flogged and the non-flogged are equal in that regard, but it mentioned “flogged” because through it the existence of fornication is established. Flogging is an expiation for him; but if he does not repent, it is an expiation for the sin that occurred from him only. As for if he persists, then the flogging does not expiate his persistence, and he is not married to a chaste woman. But if it happens that a fornicator is contracted in marriage to a chaste woman, the contract is valid and it is not said: the contract is void, even if he is not a suitable match for her.
As for the chaste man, many scholars permitted him to marry the fornicatress, using as evidence Allah the Exalted’s statement: {Marry off the unmarried among you} (al-Nur: 32).

P6709 - Biographies of the men in the chain of the hadith: (A flogged fornicator does not marry except one like him)
His statement: [He said: Musaddad narrated to us.]
He is Musaddad ibn Musarhad, and he is trustworthy; al-Bukhari, Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and al-Nasa'i narrated from him.
[And Abū Muʿammar.]
He is ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿAmr ibn Abī al-Ḥajjāj, and he is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[ʿAbd al-Wārith narrated to us.]
He is ʿAbd al-Wārith ibn Saʿīd al-ʿAnbarī, and he is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Ḥabīb.]
He is Ḥabīb al-Muʿallim, and he is truthful; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb, from Saʿīd al-Maqburī.]
ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb has already been mentioned, and Saʿīd al-Maqburī is trustworthy; the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From Abū Hurayrah.]
He is ʿAbd al-Raḥmān ibn Ṣakhr al-Dawsī, the Companion of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and the most prolific of his Companions in hadith without exception—may Allah be pleased with him and grant him pleasure.
[And Abū Muʿammar said: Ḥabīb al-Muʿallim narrated to me, from ʿAmr ibn Shuʿayb.]
Meaning: the wording he cited is upon the wording of the first shaykh, Musaddad; then he informed about the second shaykh. The narration from Abū Muʿammar came with the additional word “al-Muʿallim” appended to Ḥabīb; also, the first was with the wording “from,” while here it is with the wording of direct narration.

P6710 - A man frees his slave-girl, then marries her

P6711 - Explanation of the hadith: (Whoever frees his slave-girl, then marries her, has two rewards)
The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: A man frees his slave-girl, then marries her.
Hannād ibn al-Sarī narrated to us; ʿAbthar narrated to us, from Muṭarrif, from ʿĀmir, from Abū Burdah, from Abū Mūsā, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (Whoever frees his slave-girl and marries her has two rewards).]
Abu Dawud cited this chapter heading—[Chapter: A man frees his slave-girl and marries her]—meaning: that this is valid and that it contains tremendous reward. That is because the Prophet ﷺ said, as in the hadith of Abū Mūsā: (He has two rewards), meaning: a reward for his emancipation and a reward for his kindness to her through emancipation and marriage. He married her, and she came to have a right to an allotted turn after previously having no allotted turn. Thus he treated her well by transferring her from a state in which she had no allotted turn to a state in which she is among the wives for whom turns are allotted; so he has two rewards: a reward for his emancipation and his kindness to her by emancipating her, and a reward for his kindness to her by marrying her, and for her becoming among his wives who have the right to an allotted turn.
