P6802 - Questions

P6803 - Jābir, may Allah be pleased with him, hiding in order to see the woman he intended to propose to: was that in his first marriage?
In the hadith, Jābir was hiding to see the one he wanted to marry; so is she the one the Prophet ﷺ asked him about when he said: (Have you married? He said: Yes. He said: A virgin or a previously married woman? He said: A previously married woman, O Messenger of Allah ﷺ!), or is it the story of another marriage of Jābir?

P6803a - The answer
There is nothing indicating that she was the same woman, so it could have been her or someone else.

P6804 - What may be looked at of the body of the woman being proposed to

P6804a - The question
What is it that may be looked at of the woman being proposed to? Is it permissible to look at other than the face and the two hands?

P6804b - The answer
He looks only at the two hands and the face, and he does not go beyond that. There is disagreement: some scholars say he may look at her hair, and some hold that looking at more than that is permissible, and this is what is transmitted from Ibn Hazm.

P6805 - Ruling on seeking permission from a woman’s paternal cousins when intending to marry her

P6805a - The question
Among some tribes, whoever intends to marry a woman must seek permission from her paternal cousins; what is the ruling on this?

P6805b - The answer
This is from the matters of al-Jahiliyyah; her paternal cousins do not own her, and they have no right to prevent her from marrying whom she wants.

P6806 - Ruling on writing some verses in a vessel so that the one whose childbirth is difficult may be given its water to drink

P6806a - The question
Shaykh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah Most High have mercy on him, said: It is permissible to write, for the afflicted person and others among the sick, something from the Book of Allah and His remembrance with permissible ink, and it is washed and drunk, as Ahmad and others stated. Abdullah, the son of Imam Ahmad, said: I read to my father: Yaʿlā ibn ʿUbayd narrated to us; Sufyān narrated to us; from Muḥammad ibn Abī Laylā; from al-Ḥakam; from Saʿīd ibn Jubayr; from Ibn ʿAbbās, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: If childbirth becomes difficult for a woman, then let him write: (In the name of Allah. There is no deity but Allah, the Forbearing, the Generous. Glory be to Allah, Lord of the Magnificent Throne. All praise is for Allah, Lord of the worlds [al-Fātiḥah: 2]. As if, on the day they see it, they had not remained except an evening or its forenoon [al-Nāziʿāt: 46]. As if, on the day they see what they are promised, they had not remained except an hour of a day. A conveyance, so shall any be destroyed except the defiantly disobedient people [al-Aḥqāf: 35].)
My father said: Aswad ibn ʿĀmir narrated to us, with his isnad, with its meaning; and he said: It is written in a clean vessel and then she is given to drink.
My father said: And Wakīʿ added to it: then she is given to drink, and that which is below her navel is sprinkled.
Abdullah said: I saw my father write for a woman in an ijānah, or something clean, and so on to the end.
Shaykh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah نقل this statement in (Majmuʿ al-Fatāwā).
So it is understood from what he نقل that it is written for a woman in a clean vessel, then she is given to drink and that which is below her navel is sprinkled with it, in order to facilitate childbirth; and he نقل it from Ahmad. So is this act sound?

P6806b - The answer
This isnad is not authentic from Ibn Abbas, so long as it contains Muhammad ibn Abi Layla. As for what is reported from some of the salaf, as Ibn Taymiyyah mentioned, and likewise Ibn al-Qayyim in the book (Zad al-Maʿad), regarding writing verses on occasions and in various situations, then it appears—and Allah knows best—that leaving that is better, because there is no evidence for it.

P6807 - What al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar meant by his stipulating soundness or hasan for what he نقل from the principal musnads, jawamiʿ, and others in al-Fath

P6807a - The question
Al-Hafiz, may Allah Most High have mercy on him, said in the introduction to (Hady al-Sari): “Then I extract, secondly, what relates to that hadith, for a valid purpose, of the benefits of the text and the chain: of completions and additions, uncovering an obscurity, an explicit statement by a mudallis of having heard, and a corroboration by one who heard from a shaykh who had mixed up before that, extracting all of that from the principal musnads, jawamiʿ, mustakhraj works, ajzaʾ, and fawaʾid, on the condition of soundness or hasan regarding what I mention thereof.”
End of quote.
So what did al-Hafiz mean by his statement: “on the condition of soundness or hasan”? Is everything al-Hafiz brought in al-Fath judged by this ruling, as is common among students of knowledge, or is the ruling restricted to what he detailed, may Allah have mercy on him, of benefits, completions, and additions related to the hadith being explained and discussed?

P6807b - The answer
This statement is understood to mean that if he speaks about it as weak or as sound, then the intended meaning of his specified statement has been achieved; but if he is silent about it and does not mention anything, then what this statement entails is that it is sound or hasan, according to his words, may Allah Most High have mercy on him.

P6808 - Ruling on leaving a sunnah practice for the sake of winning hearts over

P6808a - The question
Is it permissible to leave a sunnah practice for the interest of daʿwah, and to win hearts over?

P6808b - The answer
Winning hearts over is by following the Sunnah and calling to it, not by leaving sunnah practices in order to obtain something that he may not obtain; thus he has lost this and that.

P6809 - Ruling on greeting a woman when there is a need to speak with her

P6809a - The question
A man may be compelled to speak with a young woman about some matter from behind a veil; does he begin the conversation with salam and end it with salam?

P6809b - The answer
The beginning of speech is the salam. But speaking with a young woman or with others is only within the bounds of the intended and required purpose: for example, he calls on the telephone and a woman answers; first he gives salam, then he asks about the person: is he present or not present? and he ends at this limit. There should not be any drawn-out conversation, back and forth.

P6810 - Clarifying the principle: (There is no rebuke in issues of disagreement)

P6810a - The question
What do you say about one who says that there is no rebuke regarding the issue of singing with musical instruments, and likewise the issue of acting, on the pretext that the ummah’s disagreement is a mercy and on the juristic principle: there is no rebuke in issues of disagreement?

P6810b - The answer
Not every disagreement is considered. What is relied upon is the evidences, and if the evidence becomes clear and is present, then it is not permissible to oppose it. It is not permissible to abandon rebuke because someone has differed in that, because what matters is the establishment of the evidence and the manifestation of the truth, even if someone says otherwise. One does not leave the truth because there is disagreement about it. If it were the case that anything in which there is disagreement is not spoken about, then there would be no clarification of the truth. Rather, among disputed issues are those in which the other statement has no evidence for it, or it is ijtihad in opposition to a text, or analogical reasoning in opposition to a clear, manifest text. So clarification and explanation are necessary.

P6811 - Ruling on men beating the duff at weddings

P6811a - The question
Is it permissible for men to beat the duff in a wedding celebration?

P6811b - The answer
That is not permissible for men; rather, it is permissible only for women, because it has been reported concerning women and it has not been reported concerning men.

P6812 - Ruling on feasts before the wedding

P6812a - The question
What some people do of feasts before the marriage contract, of what is called the shabka and the like—does that count as extravagance?

P6812b - The answer
There is no doubt that it is from affectation and from things that burden the husband. Leaving these things, and sufficing with a single walimah without exaggeration in it, is what should be done.

P6813 - Extent of the soundness of the statement that Jesus, peace be upon him, will be buried beside the Prophet ﷺ

P6813a - The question
Some people say: Jesus, peace be upon him, will be buried beside the grave of the Prophet ﷺ. How sound is this statement?

P6813b - The answer
I do not know anything about its soundness.

P6814 - Meaning of the Prophet’s ﷺ statement: (And I am a security for my Companions)

P6814a - The question
In a hadith from the Prophet ﷺ it says: (The stars are a security for the sky; when the stars depart, the sky will come what it has been promised; and I am a security for my Companions.) What is meant by his statement: (I am a security for my Companions)?

P6814b - The answer
Its meaning is that his presence among them was a security for them from the disagreement that occurred after his death ﷺ, and the hadith is authentic and established from the Messenger of Allah ﷺ.

P6815 - Response regarding the hadith about some Companions practicing mutʿah until the time of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him

P6815a - The question
In the hadith it says: (We used to practice mutʿah for days with a handful of dates and flour during the time of the Prophet ﷺ and Abu Bakr, until Umar forbade it.) What is the response to this hadith, since it indicates that the prohibition of mutʿah was delayed?

P6815b - The answer
Ibn al-Qayyim said in (Zad al-Maʿad fi Hady Khayr al-ʿIbad), may Allah Most High have mercy on him: If it is said: What do you do with what Muslim narrated in his Sahih from Jabir ibn Abd Allah, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he said: We used to practice mutʿah for days with a handful of dates and flour during the time of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, until Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, forbade it concerning Amr ibn Harith; and with what is established from Umar that he said: Two mutʿahs were during the time of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and I forbid them: the mutʿah of women and the mutʿah of Hajj.
It is said: People regarding this are two groups. One group says: Umar is the one who prohibited it and forbade it, and the Messenger of Allah ﷺ commanded following what the Rightly Guided Caliphs instituted. This group did not view as authentic the hadith of Sabrah ibn Maʿbad regarding the prohibition of mutʿah in the year of the Conquest, for it is from the narration of Abd al-Malik ibn al-Rabiʿ ibn Sabrah from his father from his grandfather, and Ibn Maʿin spoke against him. Al-Bukhari did not see fit to include his hadith in his Sahih despite the severe need for it, and its being a foundational principle of Islam; had it been authentic with him, he would not have refrained from including it and using it as proof.
They said: If the hadith of Sabrah were authentic, it would not have been hidden from Ibn Masʿud, may Allah be pleased with him, such that he would narrate that they did it and cite the verse as proof. Also, if it were authentic, Umar would not have said: It was during the time of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and I forbid it and punish for it; rather, he would have said: He ﷺ prohibited it and forbade it. They said: And if it were authentic, it would not have been practiced during the time of al-Siddiq, which truly was the time of the caliphate of Prophethood.
The second group held the hadith of Sabrah to be authentic. And even if it were not authentic, the hadith of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah ﷺ prohibited the mutʿah of women is authentic. Therefore, it is necessary to interpret the hadith of Jabir as meaning that the one who reported its being practiced had not received news of the prohibition, and it had not become widespread until the time of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him. When dispute about it occurred, its prohibition became manifest and widespread, and thus the hadiths narrated regarding it are reconciled. And Allah is the One who grants success.
This clarifies what is meant: that news reaches them, and after that it became widespread and manifest in the time of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him and be pleased with him. Something similar to this is the hadith of A’ishah, may Allah Most High be pleased with her: (Among what was revealed of the Quran were ten known sucklings that made marriage unlawful; then they were abrogated by five known; and the Messenger of Allah ﷺ passed away while they were among what was recited of the Quran.) Even though they were abrogated, because the time was close, some people after the death of the Messenger ﷺ would recite them and did not know of the abrogation. So this is of this type, as Ibn al-Qayyim said.

P6816 - Ruling on the guardian stipulating for the husband that he not marry over his ward

P6816a - The question
May the woman’s guardian stipulate in the contract that the husband not marry another wife besides his daughter?

P6816b - The answer
There is no harm in that, because he wants that his daughter not be harmed and that nothing occur that harms her. Whoever does not want this should seek someone else; the matter is broad. But what is blameworthy is that a woman already exists and then another woman comes and stipulates the divorce of the existing one who has obtained provision and good. As for what is mentioned in the question, there is no harm in it.

P6817 - Ruling on preventing the suitor from looking at his fiancée

P6817a - The question
We have a custom in which we do not allow the suitor to look at the woman he is proposing to, and if he requests it we prevent him. Is there any sin upon us?

P6817b - The answer
As for sin, I do not know of it. Looking is not obligatory, and the Prophet’s ﷺ statement: (If you are able to look) indicates that there can be a marriage without looking.

P6818 - An advisory word to students of knowledge during the vacation days

P6818a - The question
In view of the end of studies for this year, and the fact that all the students are returning to their countries, we hope for your guidance to the students in calling to Allah, Glorified and Exalted.

P6818b - The answer
This vacation is an opportunity for a person to seize and benefit from, and not let it be wasted without benefit, by doing what he can do that returns to him with good and returns to others with good: through reading and study, and reading some beneficial, useful books; or undertaking calling to Allah, Mighty and Majestic, and calling to good; or teaching some people who are in need of being taught, so he teaches them the matters of their religion and gives them understanding in them. This is part of calling to Allah, Mighty and Majestic, because calling to Allah is through teaching, and it is through reminding: there are people whom he teaches and people whom he reminds, and all of that is part of calling to Allah, Mighty and Majestic. The important matter is that a person benefits from the vacation and does not let the opportunity be wasted on himself, without using it in what returns to him and to others with good.
If a person does not have the ability to call to Allah, Mighty and Majestic, and to teach others, then at the very least he should read some beneficial, useful books such as the book (Iʿlam al-Muwaqqiʿin) by Ibn al-Qayyim. It is a precious book containing tremendous knowledge, and mentioning principles in the Shariʿah and the wisdoms of legal rulings; it contains fundamentals and branches. Likewise, the book (Zad al-Maʿad fi Hady Khayr al-ʿIbad) is a great book. If he reads books like these, and he comes out of the vacation having read such books, then he will have come out with profit and benefit. If he does not accustom himself to doing such work, the vacation will end and he will not have profited from it, nor attained anything of significance, because he wasted the opportunity on himself. But if, from the outset, he firmly resolves to strive and benefit from the break, then he will attain and benefit without it being wasted on him pointlessly without benefit. This is a brief advice I would like to say on this occasion.

P6819 - Stance toward the book al-Asas fi al-Tafsir and its author

P6819a - The question
What is your view of the book al-Asas fi al-Tafsir by Saʿid Hawwa, and what is your view of its author?

P6819b - The answer
I do not know the book, but I know that the author of the book is confused and mixed up, and it is not suitable that anything from his books be read because of what they contain of confusion. A person should read reliable books and beneficial books from which he comes out with benefit, such as the two books that I pointed to: (Iʿlam al-Muwaqqiʿin) and (Zad al-Maʿad); and such as the tafsir of Shaykh Ibn Saʿdi. If a person wants to read a reliable tafsir and a clear tafsir that he can read and complete, with clear and plain expressions, then he should read the tafsir of Shaykh Abd al-Rahman ibn Saʿdi, may Allah have mercy on him. It is a valuable and great tafsir suitable for the general public and the elite, because it is in clear expressions that both the specialist and the general person understand. It does not contain: “it was said such-and-such, and it was said such-and-such, and it was said such-and-such,” for these are things that may confuse the general public. Rather, its expressions are clear and plain: it analyzes the verses and clarifies their meanings in clear, plain, understandable expressions. The reader should read from people who have safety from confusion, who are people of knowledge and not people of new methodologies that deviate from the straight path.

P6820 - What is to be done after a shighar marriage done in ignorance

P6820a - The question
If two people marry by way of shighar while being ignorant of the ruling, are they separated?

P6820b - The answer
If mutual acceptance and harmony are present, then the contract is renewed.

P6821 - The time of looking at the woman being proposed to

P6821a - The question
Is looking at the woman being proposed to before the proposal, or after it?

P6821b - The answer
Some of the people of knowledge said: it is before the proposal. If he resolves to propose to her, then he looks at her before he proposes to her. They said: if he proposes to her and then sees her after that, he may not desire her; and this is only by way of hiding. As for by way of requesting, there is no way to see her unless he is a suitor.

P6822 - Explanation of Sunan Abi Dawud [240]
Marriage is among the greatest matters that Islam has regulated, and it has made it a fortress for preserving honor and limiting the spread of indecencies. The Shariʿah has stipulated that marriage be conducted through the woman’s guardian, and it has invalidated a marriage if it is without the guardian’s permission.

P6823 - Guardianship in marriage

P6824 - Explanation of the hadith: (Any woman who marries without the permission of her guardians, then her marriage is invalid)
The compiler, may Allah Most High have mercy on him, said: [Chapter on the guardian.
Muḥammad ibn Kathīr narrated to us; Sufyān informed us; Ibn Jurayj informed us, from Sulaymān ibn Mūsā, from al-Zuhrī, from ʿUrwah, from ʿĀʾishah, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (Any woman who marries without the permission of her guardians, then her marriage is invalid—three times. If he consummates with her, then the mahr is hers for what he has taken from her; and if they dispute, then the ruler is the guardian of one who has no guardian.)].
Imam Abu Dawud al-Sijistani, may Allah Most High have mercy on him, says: [Chapter on the guardian].
That is: the guardian who undertakes the marriage contract on behalf of the husband with a woman. It is necessary that she have a guardian to undertake that; she does not undertake it herself, nor does a stranger who is not among her guardians undertake it, except by deputization from the guardian. Guardianship in marriage existed in al-Jahiliyyah, as has come in Sahih al-Bukhari from A’ishah, may Allah be pleased with her, that in al-Jahiliyyah a man would come to a man and propose his ward from him, and he would marry her to him. So this ruling—namely, the necessity of a guardian in marriage—was among the matters that existed in al-Jahiliyyah, and Islam affirmed it.

P6825 - The wisdom in considering the guardian in marriage and the evidences for stipulating it in the Book and the Sunnah
It is known that the Sunnah of the Messenger ﷺ is by speech, action, and approval. The Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ has come with stipulating the guardian, as in the hadith that Abu Dawud and others cited. That has also come in the Noble Quran, and there has also come approval of this ruling that existed in al-Jahiliyyah, and that it is among the rulings that existed and that Islam affirmed.
This is something commendable, because in it is keeping the woman away from appearing by being preoccupied with marriage, and modesty predominates over them. Thus the Book and the Sunnah came with stipulating the guardian in marriage, and that it is necessary that a woman have a guardian who contracts the marriage for her to the one who will marry her. In the Quran there is what indicates this, in the statement of Allah, Mighty and Majestic: “So do not prevent them from marrying their husbands” [al-Baqarah: 232]. It is an address to the guardians. If a woman were able to conclude the contract for herself, or someone other than her guardians could do that, then there would have been no need to forbid the guardians from preventing them, when they prevent them from marrying their husbands.
This is because the verse was revealed regarding Maʿqil ibn Yasar, may Allah be pleased with him. He had a sister whom he married off to a relative of his; then he divorced her. When her waiting period ended, he came to propose to her again, and Maʿqil swore that he would not marry her to him. That reached the Prophet ﷺ, and the verse was revealed: “So do not prevent them from marrying their husbands,” meaning: those who divorced them and whose waiting period ended.
As for when he divorced her while she was still in the waiting period, then the matter belongs to the husband, because he has the right of return. But when the woman exits the waiting period, he becomes one suitor among the suitors. If she wishes to return to him, her guardian does not prevent her from that; and if she wishes not to accept him, and she desires another person besides him, then she may do so.
So this noble verse contains a forbiddance to the guardians from prevention (ʿadl), which is their refusal to marry off the divorced husbands when the women are pleased with those husbands who divorced them. The guardian is thus required to contract for her with the husband who divorced her, whose waiting period ended, and who wants to marry her again. The verse is clear in indicating that guardianship is necessary, because if it were not necessary there would have been no need to forbid them; rather, she would dispose of her own affair if the matter were up to her. The Sunnah of the Messenger ﷺ has come with hadiths that Abu Dawud cited in this chapter, and he cited hadiths indicating that the guardian is necessary in marriage.
He first cited the hadith of the Mother of the Believers A’ishah, may Allah be pleased with her and cause her to be pleasing, that the Prophet ﷺ said: (Any woman who marries without the permission of her guardians, then her marriage is invalid—three times), meaning that he said: invalid, invalid, invalid. He repeated that for emphasis. He said: (If he consummates with her, then the mahr is hers for what he has taken from her; and if they dispute, then the ruler is the guardian of one who has no guardian.)
The Messenger of Allah’s ﷺ statement: (Any woman who marries without the permission of her guardians, then her marriage is invalid) indicates that guardianship is a condition in marriage, and that if the contract is concluded without a guardian then it is invalid. If a woman contracts for herself, or authorizes someone to contract for her, and she is the one who undertakes that without the permission of the guardians, then it is invalid, as the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said. This is general, meaning that any woman for whom that occurs without a guardian, the marriage is invalid, and it is null as if it never occurred, because it has lost this condition, which is the guardian in marriage.
What is intended by his statement: (the permission of her guardians) is that they conclude the contract or permit someone to conclude it; that is, either the guardian concludes it himself, or he permits someone to conclude it on his behalf.
The intent is that marriage is not valid unless it is from a guardian or an agent of a guardian. It is not intended that a woman may marry herself off with her guardian’s permission, because she does not have guardianship in concluding the marriage contract for herself.
The guardian is the one among her agnatic relatives, the nearest then the nearest: the father, then the grandfather, then the son, then the son’s son, then the full brother, then the brother by the father, then the full brother’s son, then the brother-by-father’s son, then the full paternal uncle, then the paternal uncle by the father, then the full paternal uncle’s son, then the paternal uncle-by-father’s son, and so on according to the order. Other than the agnates are not guardians: neither uterine relatives, nor those who inherit by fixed shares, such as brothers by the mother.
The guardian who undertakes the contract must be adult. Ascendants are given precedence over others, descendants are given precedence over collateral relatives, and if the lower guardian concludes the contract while the higher exists, it is valid if the higher approves it. If the one entitled to it relinquishes it to one below him, then the contract is valid.

P6826 - Invalidating the contract that is devoid of a guardian
Then he said: (If he consummates with her), meaning: if he enters upon her by this contract that is not sound, (then the mahr is hers for what he has taken from her), meaning: what he gave her as a mahr is not returned to him so long as he has taken her and had intercourse with her, because it is hers in exchange for what he made lawful of her private part.
If the guardians dispute—meaning that they differ or they prevent—then guardianship transfers to the ruler: (the ruler is the guardian of one who has no guardian). This also indicates that the woman has no right to conclude the marriage contract, since the Shariʿah has placed that right with the guardians, then it transfers to the ruler and does not transfer to her. The matter returns to the guardians; then if they do not exist, or they exist but they are preventing and refusing to fulfill her wish and marry her to one who is suitable to marry her, then that matter transfers to the ruler, due to his statement: (and if they dispute, then the ruler is the guardian of one who has no guardian)."""

His statement: [Musaddad narrated to us from ʿAbd al-Wāḥid ibn Ziyād].

He is Wāqid ibn ʿAbd al-Raḥmān ibn Saʿd ibn Muʿādh, and it says in (Tuhfat al-Ashraf): what is known is that he is Wāqid ibn ʿAmr ibn Saʿd ibn Muʿādh.
Al-Hafiz said: its men are trustworthy, and Ibn al-Qattan declared it defective due to Wāqid ibn ʿAbd al-Raḥmān, and said: what is known is Wāqid ibn ʿAmr; and the narration of al-Hakim has: Wāqid ibn ʿAmr, and likewise the narration of al-Shafi'i and Abd al-Razzaq.
And in (Tuhfat al-Ashraf): thus it was said, Wāqid ibn ʿAbd al-Raḥmān, and what is known is Wāqid ibn ʿAmr ibn Saʿd ibn Muʿādh. The wording of al-Hakim in al-Mustadrak supports it, but al-Mizzi distinguished between the two in his Tahdhib, and he increased the distinction between them and emphasized it, and al-Hafiz also affirmed it in (Tahdhib al-Tahdhib).
This was stated by Shaykh al-Albani.
And Wāqid ibn ʿAmr ibn Saʿd ibn Muʿādh is trustworthy; Muslim, Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and al-Nasa'i narrated from him.
[from Jābir ibn ʿAbd Allāh, may Allah Most High be pleased with them both] has been mentioned previously.

P6802 - Questions

P6803 - Jābir, may Allah be pleased with him, hiding in order to see the woman he intended to propose to: was that in his first marriage?
In the hadith, Jābir was hiding to see the one he wanted to marry; so is she the one the Prophet ﷺ asked him about when he said: (Have you married? He said: Yes. He said: A virgin or a previously married woman? He said: A previously married woman, O Messenger of Allah ﷺ!), or is it the story of another marriage of Jābir?

P6803a - The answer
There is nothing indicating that she was the same woman, so it could have been her or someone else.

P6804 - What may be looked at of the body of the woman being proposed to

P6804a - The question
What is it that may be looked at of the woman being proposed to? Is it permissible to look at other than the face and the two hands?

P6804b - The answer
He looks only at the two hands and the face, and he does not go beyond that. There is disagreement: some scholars say he may look at her hair, and some hold that looking at more than that is permissible, and this is what is transmitted from Ibn Hazm.

P6805 - Ruling on seeking permission from a woman's paternal cousins when intending to marry her

P6805a - The question
Among some tribes, whoever intends to marry a woman must seek permission from her paternal cousins; what is the ruling on this?

P6805b - The answer
This is from the matters of al-Jahiliyyah; her paternal cousins do not own her, and they have no right to prevent her from marrying whom she wants.

P6806 - Ruling on writing some verses in a vessel so that the one whose childbirth is difficult may be given its water to drink

P6806a - The question
Shaykh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah Most High have mercy on him, said: It is permissible to write, for the afflicted person and others among the sick, something from the Book of Allah and His remembrance with permissible ink, and it is washed and drunk, as Ahmad and others stated. Abdullah, the son of Imam Ahmad, said: I read to my father: Yaʿlā ibn ʿUbayd narrated to us; Sufyān narrated to us; from Muḥammad ibn Abī Laylā; from al-Ḥakam; from Saʿīd ibn Jubayr; from Ibn ʿAbbās, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: If childbirth becomes difficult for a woman, then let him write: (In the name of Allah. There is no deity but Allah, the Forbearing, the Generous. Glory be to Allah, Lord of the Mighty Throne. All praise is for Allah, Lord of the worlds [al-Fatihah: 2]. As if, on the day they see it, they had not remained except an evening or its forenoon [al-Nazi'at: 46]. As if, on the day they see what they are promised, they had not remained except an hour of a day. A conveyance, so shall any be destroyed except the defiantly disobedient people [al-Ahqaf: 35].)
My father said: Aswad ibn ʿĀmir narrated to us, with his isnad, with its meaning; and he said: It is written in a clean vessel and then she is given to drink.
My father said: And Wakīʿ added to it: then she is given to drink, and that which is below her navel is sprinkled.
Abdullah said: I saw my father write for a woman in a basin, or something clean, and so on to the end.
Shaykh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah نقل this statement in (Majmu' al-Fatawa).
So it is understood from what he نقل that it is written for a woman in a clean vessel; then she is given to drink, and that which is below her navel is sprinkled with it, in order to facilitate childbirth; and he نقل it from Ahmad. So is this act sound?

P6806b - The answer
This isnad is not authentic from Ibn Abbas so long as it contains Muhammad ibn Abi Layla. As for what is reported from some of the salaf, as Ibn Taymiyyah mentioned, and likewise Ibn al-Qayyim in the book (Zad al-Ma'ad), regarding writing verses on occasions and in various situations, then it appears—and Allah knows best—that leaving that is better, because there is no evidence for it.

P6807 - What al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar meant by his stipulating soundness or hasan for what he cited from the principal musnads, jawami', and others in al-Fath

P6807a - The question
Al-Hafiz, may Allah Most High have mercy on him, said in the introduction to (Hady al-Sari): “Then I extract, secondly, what relates to that hadith, for a valid purpose, of the benefits of the text and the chain: completions and additions, uncovering what is obscure, an explicit statement by a mudallis of hearing, and a corroboration by one who heard from a shaykh who had become confused before that; extracting all of that from the principal musnads, jawami', mustakhraj works, ajza', and fawa'id, on the condition of soundness or hasan in what I mention of that.”
End of quote.
So what did al-Hafiz mean by his statement: “on the condition of soundness or hasan”? Is everything al-Hafiz brought in al-Fath judged by this ruling, as is common among students of knowledge, or is the ruling restricted to what he detailed, may Allah have mercy on him, of benefits, completions, and additions related to the hadith being explained and discussed?

P6807b - The answer
This statement is understood to mean that if he speaks about it as weak or as sound, then the intended meaning of his specified statement has been achieved; but if he is silent about it and does not mention anything, then what this statement entails is that it is sound or hasan, according to his words, may Allah Most High have mercy on him.

P6808 - Ruling on leaving a sunnah practice for the sake of winning hearts over

P6808a - The question
Is it permissible to leave a sunnah practice for the interest of da'wah, and to win hearts over?

P6808b - The answer
Winning hearts over is by following the Sunnah and calling to it, not by leaving sunnah practices in order to obtain something that he may not obtain; thus he has lost this and that.

P6809 - Ruling on greeting a woman when there is a need to speak with her

P6809a - The question
A man may be compelled to speak with a young woman about some matter from behind a veil; does he begin the conversation with salam and end it with salam?

P6809b - The answer
The beginning of speech is the salam. But speaking with a young woman or with others is only within the bounds of the intended and required purpose, such as when he calls on the telephone and a woman answers: first he gives salam, then he asks about the person, whether he is present or not present, and he ends at this limit. There should not be any drawn-out conversation, taking and giving.

P6810 - Clarifying the principle: (There is no rebuke in issues of disagreement)

P6810a - The question
What do you say about one who says that there is no rebuke regarding the issue of singing with musical instruments, and likewise the issue of acting, on the pretext that the ummah's disagreement is a mercy, and on the juristic principle: there is no rebuke in issues of disagreement?

P6810b - The answer
Not every disagreement is considered. What is relied upon is the evidences, and if the evidence becomes clear and is present, then it is not permissible to oppose it. It is not permissible to abandon rebuke because someone has differed in that, because what matters is the establishment of the evidence and the manifestation of the truth, even if someone says otherwise. One does not leave the truth because there is disagreement about it. If it were the case that anything in which there is disagreement is not spoken about, then there would be no clarification of the truth. Rather, among disputed issues are those in which the other view has no evidence, or it is ijtihad in the face of a text, or analogy in the face of a clear and manifest text; therefore explanation and clarification are necessary.

P6811 - Ruling on men beating the duff at weddings

P6811a - The question
Is it permissible for men to beat the duff in a wedding celebration?

P6811b - The answer
That is not permissible for men; rather, it is permissible only for women, because it has been reported concerning women and it has not been reported concerning men.

P6812 - Ruling on feasts before the wedding

P6812a - The question
What some people do of feasts before the marriage contract, of what is called the shabka and the like—does that count as extravagance?

P6812b - The answer
There is no doubt that it is from affectation and from things that burden the husband. Leaving these things, and sufficing with a single walimah without exaggeration in it, is what should be done.

P6813 - Extent of the soundness of the statement that Jesus, peace be upon him, will be buried beside the Prophet ﷺ

P6813a - The question
Some people say: Jesus, peace be upon him, will be buried beside the grave of the Prophet ﷺ. How sound is this statement?

P6813b - The answer
I do not know anything about its soundness.

P6814 - Meaning of the Prophet's ﷺ statement: (And I am a security for my Companions)

P6814a - The question
In a hadith from the Prophet ﷺ it says: (The stars are a security for the sky; when the stars depart, the sky will come what it has been promised; and I am a security for my Companions.) What is meant by his statement: (I am a security for my Companions)?

P6814b - The answer
Its meaning is that his presence among them was a security for them from the disagreement that occurred after his death ﷺ, and the hadith is sound and established from the Messenger of Allah ﷺ.

P6815 - Response regarding the hadith about some Companions practicing mut'ah until the time of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him

P6815a - The question
In the hadith it says: (We used to practice mut'ah for days with a handful of dates and flour during the time of the Prophet ﷺ and Abu Bakr, until Umar forbade it.) What is the response to this hadith, since it indicates that the prohibition of mut'ah was delayed?

P6815b - The answer
Ibn al-Qayyim said in (Zad al-Ma'ad fi Hady Khayr al-'Ibad), may Allah Most High have mercy on him: If it is said: What do you do with what Muslim narrated in his Sahih from Jabir ibn Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he said: We used to practice mut'ah for days with a handful of dates and flour during the time of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, until Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, forbade it concerning Amr ibn Harith; and with what is established from Umar that he said: Two mut'ahs were during the time of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and I forbid them: the mut'ah of women and the mut'ah of Hajj.
It is said: People regarding this are two groups. One group says: Umar is the one who prohibited it and forbade it. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ commanded following what the Rightly Guided Caliphs instituted. This group did not view as authentic the hadith of Sabrah ibn Ma'bad regarding the prohibition of mut'ah in the year of the Conquest. It is from the narration of Abd al-Malik ibn al-Rabi' ibn Sabrah from his father from his grandfather, and Ibn Ma'in spoke against him. Al-Bukhari did not see fit to include his hadith in his Sahih, despite the severe need for it and its being a foundational principle of Islam; and if it had been authentic to him, he would not have refrained from including it and using it as proof.
They said: If the hadith of Sabrah were authentic, it would not have been hidden from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, such that he would narrate that they did it and cite the verse as proof. Also, if it were authentic, Umar would not have said: It was during the time of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and I forbid it and punish for it; rather, he would have said: He ﷺ prohibited it and forbade it. They said: And if it were authentic, it would not have been practiced during the time of al-Siddiq, which truly was the time of the caliphate of Prophethood.
The second group held the hadith of Sabrah to be authentic; and even if it were not authentic, the hadith of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah ﷺ prohibited the mut'ah of women is authentic. Therefore, it is necessary to interpret the hadith of Jabir as meaning that the one who reported its being practiced did not have the prohibition reach him, and it had not become widespread until the time of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him. When dispute about it occurred, its prohibition became manifest and widespread, and by this the hadiths narrated regarding it are harmonized, and by Allah is the granting of success.
This clarifies what is meant, and that it reaches them, and after that it became widespread and manifest in the time of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him and grant him His pleasure. Something similar to this is the hadith of A'ishah, may Allah Most High be pleased with her: (Among what was revealed of the Quran were ten known sucklings that made unlawful; then they were abrogated by five known; and the Messenger of Allah ﷺ passed away while they were among what was recited of the Quran.) Even though they were abrogated, because the time was close, some people after the Messenger's ﷺ death would recite them and did not know of the abrogation. This is of this type, as Ibn al-Qayyim said.

P6816 - Ruling on the guardian stipulating for the husband that he not marry over his ward

P6816a - The question
May the woman's guardian stipulate in the contract that the husband not marry another wife besides his daughter?

P6816b - The answer
There is no harm in that, because he wants that his daughter not be harmed and that nothing occur that harms her. Whoever does not want this should seek someone else; the matter is broad. But what is blameworthy is that a woman already exists and then another woman comes and stipulates the divorce of the existing one who has obtained provision and good. As for what is mentioned in the question, there is no harm in it.

P6817 - Ruling on preventing the suitor from looking at his fiancée

P6817a - The question
We have a custom in which we do not allow the suitor to look at the woman he is proposing to, and if he requests it we prevent him. Is there any sin upon us?

P6817b - The answer
I do not know of sin occurring, and looking is not obligatory. The Prophet's ﷺ statement: (If you are able to look) indicates that there can be a marriage without looking.

P6818 - An advisory word to students of knowledge during the vacation days

P6818a - The question
In view of the end of studies for this year, and the fact that all the students are returning to their countries, we hope for your guidance to the students in calling to Allah, Glorified and Exalted.

P6818b - The answer
This vacation is an opportunity for a person to seize and benefit from, and not let it be wasted without benefit. That is by doing whatever he can do that returns to him with good and returns to others with good: through reading and study and reading some beneficial, useful books; or undertaking calling to Allah, Mighty and Majestic, and calling to good; or teaching some people who are in need of being taught, so he teaches them the matters of their religion and gives them understanding in them. This is part of calling to Allah, Mighty and Majestic, because calling to Allah is by teaching and by reminding: to people he teaches, and to people he reminds. All of that is calling to Allah, Mighty and Majestic. What matters is that a person benefits from the vacation and does not let the opportunity be lost to him, without using it for what brings him and others good.
If a person does not have the ability to call to Allah, Mighty and Majestic, and to teach others, then at the very least he should read some beneficial, useful books, such as the book (I'lam al-Muwaqqi'in) by Ibn al-Qayyim. It is a precious book containing tremendous knowledge, mentioning principles in the Shari'ah and the wisdoms of legal rulings; it contains fundamentals and branches. Likewise, the book (Zad al-Ma'ad fi Hady Khayr al-'Ibad) is a great book. If he reads books like these, and he comes out of the vacation having read such books, then he will have come out with profit and benefit. If he does not train himself to do such work, then the vacation will end and he will not have profited in it anything, nor achieved anything considerable, because he has missed the opportunity for himself. But if he resolves from the beginning to strive and benefit from the break, then he will achieve and benefit without it being wasted upon him with no benefit. This is a brief advice that I like to say on this occasion.

P6819 - Stance toward the book al-Asas fi al-Tafsir and its author

P6819a - The question
What is your view of the book al-Asas fi al-Tafsir by Sa'id Hawwa, and what is your view of its author?

P6819b - The answer
I do not know the book, but I know that the author of the book is confused and mixed up, and it is not suitable that anything from his books be read because of what they contain of confusion. A person should read reliable books and beneficial books from which he comes out with benefit, such as the two books that I pointed to: (I'lam al-Muwaqqi'in) and (Zad al-Ma'ad), and such as the tafsir of Shaykh Ibn Sa'di. If a person wants to read a reliable tafsir and a clear tafsir that he can read and complete, with clear and manifest expressions, then he should read the tafsir of Shaykh Abd al-Rahman ibn Sa'di, may Allah have mercy on him. It is a valuable and great tafsir, suitable for both the common people and the elite, because it is in clear expressions that both the elite and the common understand. It does not contain: “It was said such-and-such, and it was said such-and-such, and it was said such-and-such,” for these are things that can confuse the common people. Its expressions are clear and manifest; he analyzes the verses and clarifies their meanings with clear, manifest, understandable expressions. The reader should read from people who are safe from confusion, who are people of knowledge and not people of new methodologies that deviate from the straight path.

P6820 - What is to be done after a shighar marriage done in ignorance

P6820a - The question
If two people marry by way of shighar while being ignorant of the ruling, are they separated?

P6820b - The answer
If mutual acceptance and harmony are present, then the contract is renewed.

P6821 - The time of looking at the woman being proposed to

P6821a - The question
Is looking at the woman being proposed to before the proposal, or after it?

P6821b - The answer
Some of the people of knowledge said: it is before the proposal. If he resolves to propose to her, then he looks at her before he proposes to her. They said: if he proposes to her and then sees her after that, he may not desire her; and this is only by way of hiding. As for by way of requesting, there is no way to see her unless he is a suitor.

P6822 - Sharh Sunan Abi Dawud [240]
Marriage is among the greatest matters that Islam has regulated, and it has made it a fortress for preserving honor and limiting the spread of indecencies. The Shari'ah has stipulated that marriage issue from the woman's guardian, and it has invalidated a marriage if it is without the guardian's permission.

P6823 - Guardianship in marriage

P6824 - Explanation of the hadith: (Any woman who marries without the permission of her guardians, then her marriage is invalid)
The compiler, may Allah Most High have mercy on him, said: [Chapter on the guardian.
Muḥammad ibn Kathīr narrated to us; Sufyān informed us; Ibn Jurayj informed us, from Sulaymān ibn Mūsā, from al-Zuhrī, from ʿUrwah, from ʿĀʾishah, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (Any woman who marries without the permission of her guardians, then her marriage is invalid—three times. If he consummates with her, then the mahr is hers for what he has taken from her; and if they dispute, then the ruler is the guardian of one who has no guardian.)].
Imam Abu Dawud al-Sijistani, may Allah Most High have mercy on him, says: [Chapter on the guardian].
That is: the guardian who undertakes the marriage contract for a man with a woman. It is necessary that she have a guardian who undertakes that; she does not undertake it herself, nor does a stranger who is not among her guardians undertake it, except by deputization from the guardian. Guardianship in marriage existed in al-Jahiliyyah, as has come in Sahih al-Bukhari from A'ishah, may Allah be pleased with her, that in al-Jahiliyyah a man would come to a man and propose his ward from him, and he would marry her to him. Thus this ruling, namely the obligation of the guardian in marriage, is among the matters that existed in al-Jahiliyyah and that Islam affirmed.

P6825 - The wisdom in considering the guardian in marriage and the evidences for stipulating it in the Book and the Sunnah
It is known that the Sunnah of the Messenger ﷺ is by speech, action, and approval. The Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ has come with stipulating the guardian, as in the hadith that Abu Dawud and others cited. That has also come in the Noble Quran, and there has also come approval of this ruling that existed in al-Jahiliyyah, and that it is among the rulings that existed and that Islam affirmed.
This is something commendable, because in it is keeping the woman away from appearing by being preoccupied with marriage, and modesty predominates over them. Thus the Book and the Sunnah came with stipulating the guardian in marriage, and that it is necessary that a woman have a guardian who contracts the marriage for her to the one who will marry her. In the Quran there is what indicates this, in the statement of Allah, Mighty and Majestic: “So do not prevent them from marrying their husbands” [al-Baqarah: 232]. This is an address to the guardians. If a woman were able to contract for herself, or someone other than her guardians could do so, there would have been no need to forbid the guardians from prevention, when they prevent them from marrying their husbands.
This is because the verse was revealed regarding Ma'qil ibn Yasar, may Allah be pleased with him. He had a sister whom he married off to a relative of his; then he divorced her. When her waiting period ended, he came to propose to her again, and Ma'qil swore that he would not marry her to him. That reached the Prophet ﷺ, and the verse was revealed: “So do not prevent them from marrying their husbands,” meaning: those who divorced them and whose waiting period ended.
As for when he divorced her while she was still in the waiting period, then the matter belongs to the husband, because he has the right of return. But when the woman exits the waiting period, he becomes one suitor among the suitors: if she wishes to return to him, her guardian does not prevent her from that; and if she wishes not to accept him, and she desires another person besides him, then she may do so.
So this noble verse contains a forbiddance to the guardians from prevention (adl), which is their refusal to marry off the divorced husbands when the women are pleased with those husbands who divorced them. The guardian is thus required to contract for her with the husband who divorced her, whose waiting period ended, and who wants to marry her again. The verse is clear in indicating that guardianship is necessary, because if it were not necessary there would have been no need to forbid them; rather, she would manage her own affairs if it were up to her.
The Sunnah of the Messenger ﷺ includes the hadiths that Abu Dawud cited in this chapter. He cited hadiths that indicate that a guardian is necessary in marriage. He first cited the hadith of the Mother of the Believers A'ishah, may Allah be pleased with her and grant her His pleasure, that the Prophet ﷺ said: (Any woman who marries without the permission of her guardians, then her marriage is invalid—three times), meaning that he said: invalid, invalid, invalid. He repeated that for emphasis. He said: (If he consummates with her, then the mahr is hers for what he has taken from her; and if they dispute, then the ruler is the guardian of one who has no guardian.)
The Messenger of Allah's ﷺ statement: (Any woman who marries without the permission of her guardians, then her marriage is invalid) indicates that guardianship is a condition in marriage, and that if the contract is concluded without a guardian then it is invalid. If a woman contracts for herself, or authorizes someone to contract for her, and she is the one who undertakes that without the permission of the guardians, then it is invalid, as the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said. This is general, meaning that any woman for whom that occurs without a guardian, then the marriage is invalid. It is null, as though it never happened, because it has missed this condition, which is the guardian in marriage.
What is intended by his statement: (the permission of her guardians) is that they conclude the contract or permit someone to conclude it; that is, either the guardian concludes it himself, or he permits someone to conclude it on his behalf.
The intent is that marriage is not valid unless it is from a guardian or an agent of a guardian. It is not intended that a woman may marry herself off with her guardian's permission, because she does not have guardianship in concluding the marriage contract for herself.
The guardian is the one among her agnatic relatives, the nearest then the nearest: the father, then the grandfather, then the son, then the son's son, then the full brother, then the brother by the father, then the full brother's son, then the brother-by-father's son, then the full paternal uncle, then the paternal uncle by the father, then the full paternal uncle's son, then the paternal uncle-by-father's son, and so on according to the order. Other than the agnates are not guardians: neither uterine relatives nor those who inherit by fixed shares, such as maternal brothers.
The guardian who undertakes the contract must be adult. Ascendants are given precedence over others, descendants are given precedence over collateral relatives, and if the lower guardian concludes the contract while the higher exists, it is valid if the higher approves it. If the one entitled to it relinquishes it to one below him, then the contract is valid.

P6826 - Invalidating the contract that is devoid of a guardian
Then he said: (If he consummates with her), meaning: if he enters upon her by this contract that is not sound, (then the mahr is hers for what he has taken from her), meaning: what he gave her as a mahr is not returned to him so long as he has taken her and had intercourse with her, because it is hers in exchange for what he made lawful of her private part.
If the guardians dispute—meaning that they differ or they prevent—then guardianship transfers to the ruler: (the ruler is the guardian of one who has no guardian). This also indicates that the woman has no right to conclude the marriage contract, since the Shari'ah has placed that right with the guardians, then it transfers to the ruler and does not transfer to her. The matter returns to the guardians; then if they do not exist, or they exist but they are preventing and refusing to fulfill her wish and marry her to one who is suitable for marriage to her, then that matter transfers to the ruler, due to his statement: (If they dispute, then the ruler is the guardian of one who has no guardian)."""
