final_text2 = """P6750 - Does what is less than five sucklings make unlawful?

P6751 - Explanation of the hadith: “Among what Allah, Mighty and Majestic, sent down of the Qur’an were ten sucklings that make unlawful”
The compiler (may Allah Most High have mercy on him) said: [Chapter: Does what is less than five sucklings make unlawful.
ʻAbd Allāh ibn Maslamah al-Qaʻnabī narrated to us, from Mālik, from ʻAbd Allāh ibn Abī Bakr ibn Muḥammad ibn ʻAmr ibn Ḥazm, from ʻAmrah bint ʻAbd al-Raḥmān, from ʻĀʼishah (may Allah be pleased with her), that she said: Among what Allah, Mighty and Majestic, sent down of the Qur’an were ten sucklings that make unlawful; then they were abrogated by five known sucklings that make unlawful; then the Prophet ﷺ passed away while they were among what was recited of the Qur’an.]

The compiler (may Allah Most High have mercy on him) said: [Chapter: Does what is less than five sucklings make unlawful. The scholars differed regarding the suckling that causes prohibition in three views:
The first view: it is what reaches five sucklings or more, and the evidence for that is this hadith which Abu Dawud cited from ʻĀʼishah (may Allah Most High be pleased with her), who said: “Among what Allah, Mighty and Majestic, sent down of the Qur’an were ten sucklings that make unlawful, so they were abrogated by five known sucklings that make unlawful; then the Prophet ﷺ passed away while they were among what was recited of the Qur’an.”
They also argued with the hadith that previously passed concerning the suckling of an adult, in which he said: “Breastfeed him five sucklings.” It is an authentic hadith, but—as is known—it is specific to Salim, the freedman of Abu Hudhayfah. In it, the five are mentioned, so it is evidence that what is considered in suckling is what reaches five sucklings.
The second view: that what makes unlawful is three sucklings or more. They infer that from the hadith that will come, namely his statement: “A single suckle does not make unlawful, nor do two suckles.” They said: its implied meaning indicates that if it is more than that, then it makes unlawful.
The third view: that little and much suckling both make unlawful, because it has come unrestricted in some texts, such as Allah Most High’s statement: “And your mothers who breastfed you, and your sisters through suckling” (al-Nisa’ 4:23). It came unrestricted. They said: thus the little and the much make unlawful.
The correct and preponderant view among these views is the view that what makes unlawful is five sucklings, because what indicates it has come from the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, as in this hadith which Abu Dawud cited, and the hadith that has already preceded concerning the suckling of an adult.
Abu Dawud cited here the hadith of ʻĀʼishah: “Among what Allah, Mighty and Majestic, sent down of the Qur’an were ten sucklings that make unlawful; so they were abrogated by five known sucklings that make unlawful; then the Prophet ﷺ passed away while they were among what was recited of the Qur’an.”
His statement: “while they” means: the five, because the pointing is to the five. There is not in the Qur’an “five sucklings make unlawful,” but in this there is an indication of the closeness of the abrogation to the death of the Messenger ﷺ, and that some people who had not received news of the abrogation continued the recitation until the abrogation reached them, due to its being close to the death of the Messenger ﷺ. So the abrogation came late.]

P6752 - Types of abrogation in the Noble Qur’an
This hadith is evidence that prohibition is only by five sucklings, and it is also evidence for two kinds among the kinds of abrogation in the Noble Qur’an, because abrogation with respect to recitation and ruling is of three divisions:
First: abrogation of both the recitation and the ruling together.
Second: abrogation of the ruling while the recitation remains.
Third: abrogation of the recitation while the ruling remains.
This hadith contains an example of two divisions: abrogation of the recitation and the ruling in the issue of “ten known sucklings make unlawful,” because the ruling and the recitation were abrogated: the ruling is abrogated and the recitation is abrogated.
And “five sucklings make unlawful” was such that its recitation was abrogated while the ruling remained.
An example of the third division—abrogation of the ruling while the recitation remains—is the verse about the waiting period of the woman whose husband dies being a full year, namely Allah Most High’s statement: “And those of you who die and leave wives: a bequest for their wives, provision for a year, without expulsion” (al-Baqarah 2:240). Its ruling is abrogated while its recitation remains, and what abrogated it is the verse before it, namely that they wait four months and ten days. Thus the divisions of abrogation with respect to recitation and ruling are three: abrogation of recitation and ruling, and abrogation of recitation while the ruling remains, and the hadith we have is a witness to the two. And the third division is: abrogation of the ruling while the recitation remains, as a verse.

P6753 - Biographies of the men of the chain of the hadith: “Among what Allah, Mighty and Majestic, sent down of the Qur’an were ten sucklings that make unlawful”
His statement: [ʻAbd Allāh ibn Maslamah al-Qaʻnabī narrated to us].
ʻAbd Allāh ibn Maslamah al-Qaʻnabī is trustworthy; the compilers of the six books recorded his narrations except Ibn Majah.
[From Mālik].
He is Mālik ibn Anas, the Imam of the Abode of Emigration, the hadith scholar and jurist, the famous Imam, one of the Imams of the four well-known schools of the Sunnis, and the compilers of the six books recorded his hadith.
[From ʻAbd Allāh ibn Abī Bakr ibn Muḥammad ibn ʻAmr ibn Ḥazm].
ʻAbd Allāh ibn Abī Bakr ibn Muḥammad ibn ʻAmr ibn Ḥazm is trustworthy; the compilers of the six books recorded his narrations.
[From ʻAmrah].
She is ʻAmrah bint ʻAbd al-Raḥmān, and she is trustworthy; the compilers of the six books recorded her narrations.
[From ʻĀʼishah].
She is ʻĀʼishah, the Mother of the Believers (may Allah be pleased with her and make her pleased), the truthful woman, daughter of the truthful man, and she is one of seven persons known for narrating many hadiths from the Prophet ﷺ.

P6754 - Explanation of the hadith: “A single suckle does not make unlawful, nor do two suckles”
The compiler (may Allah Most High have mercy on him) said: [Musaddad ibn Musarhad narrated to us; Ismāʻīl narrated to us, from Ayyūb, from Ibn Abī Mulaykah, from ʻAbd Allāh ibn al-Zubayr (may Allah be pleased with them both), from ʻĀʼishah (may Allah be pleased with her), that she said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: “A single suckle does not make unlawful, nor do two suckles.”]

Abu Dawud cited the hadith of ʻĀʼishah (may Allah be pleased with her) that the Prophet ﷺ said: “A single suckle does not make unlawful, nor do two suckles,” meaning: one suckling and two sucklings. This is explicitly stated here, but her statement, “so they were abrogated by five known sucklings that make unlawful,” indicates that what is less than it does not make unlawful, whether the one or the two explicitly stated in this hadith, or the third and the fourth that are not stated in the hadith, but they are less than the five which came in the hadith that it makes unlawful.

P6755 - Biographies of the men of the chain of the hadith: “A single suckle does not make unlawful, nor do two suckles”
His statement: [Musaddad ibn Musarhad narrated to us].
He is Musaddad ibn Musarhad, and he is trustworthy; al-Bukhari, Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and al-Nasa’i recorded his hadith.
[Ismāʻīl narrated to us].
He is Ismāʻīl ibn ʻUlayyah, and he is trustworthy; the compilers of the six books recorded his narrations.
[From Ayyūb].
He is Ayyūb ibn Abī Tamīmah al-Sakhtiyānī, and he is trustworthy; the compilers of the six books recorded his narrations.
[From Ibn Abī Mulaykah].
He is ʻAbd Allāh ibn ʻUbayd Allāh ibn Abī Mulaykah, trustworthy; the compilers of the six books recorded his narrations.
[From ʻAbd Allāh ibn al-Zubayr].
He is ʻAbd Allāh ibn al-Zubayr (may Allah Most High be pleased with them both), the noble Companion, one of the four ʻAbd Allāhs among the Companions of the Prophet ﷺ, who are: ʻAbd Allāh ibn al-Zubayr, ʻAbd Allāh ibn ʻUmar, ʻAbd Allāh ibn ʻAmr, and ʻAbd Allāh ibn ʻAbbās (may Allah be pleased with them and with all the Companions altogether).
[From ʻĀʼishah].
Her mention has already passed.

P6756 - The gratuity at weaning

P6757 - Explanation of the hadith clarifying removal of the obligation of suckling by a ghurrah
The compiler (may Allah Most High have mercy on him) said: [Chapter: On the gratuity at weaning.
ʻAbd Allāh ibn Muḥammad al-Nufaylī narrated to us; Abū Muʻāwiyah narrated to us.
Ḥ: And Ibn al-ʻAlāʼ narrated to us; Ibn Idrīs narrated to us, from Hishām ibn ʻUrwah, from his father, from Ḥajjāj ibn Ḥajjāj, from his father (may Allah be pleased with him), that he said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! What will remove from me the obligation of suckling? He said: “A ghurrah: a male slave or a female slave.”
Al-Nufaylī said: Ḥajjāj ibn Ḥajjāj al-Aslamī.
This is its wording.]

Abu Dawud brought this chapter heading, namely [Chapter: the gratuity at weaning]. The gratuity is what is given to the wet nurse upon completion of the nursing, when her task ends and her connection with those for whom she breastfed ends. They give her her wage and they give her a gratuity not agreed upon. Part of perfect beneficence and perfect dealings is that they honor her and present her with something besides the wage that they agreed with her upon. This is what is meant by the gratuity, meaning that she is given something other than what was agreed upon as her wage.
And in this there has come the hadith of Ḥajjāj ibn Ḥajjāj al-Aslamī from his father, that he said: “O Messenger of Allah! What will remove from me the obligation of suckling?” The obligation of suckling is its right and its bond of obligation; what is meant by it is the right and the known favor that came from the wet nurse. So what will remove it from me if I do it? Is it beneficence in return for beneficence? He said: “A ghurrah,” meaning: a slave, because just as she showed beneficence to the child while he was small and breastfed him, she is given something that removes that right, and the person has discharged the right he owes.
If what is meant by it is the child who was breastfed, then that would not be at weaning; rather, it would only be later, meaning that if the nursling wants to show beneficence, he will not show beneficence except after a later time. So the gratuity at weaning is intended to be from the one who hired her, who is the child’s father, or the child’s mother, or the child’s paternal uncle, or a relative of the child. Here it is as though it suggests that what is intended by that is that the one who was breastfed wants to show beneficence to his milk-mother and to discharge the right he owes her, by giving her a male slave or a female slave to serve her, because she showed beneficence to him while he was small, and she has reached whatever age she has reached; so his giving her someone who serves her and showing beneficence to her as a recompense to her for that is what is meant by the hadith.
This hadith is weak, because in its chain is Ḥajjāj ibn Ḥajjāj, and he is acceptable: his hadith is not used as proof unless he is corroborated, and he has no corroborator here. So the hadith is not established from the Messenger of Allah ﷺ.

P6758 - Biographies of the men of the chain of the hadith clarifying removal of the obligation of suckling by a ghurrah
His statement: [ʻAbd Allāh ibn Muḥammad al-Nufaylī narrated to us].
He is ʻAbd Allāh ibn Muḥammad ibn Nufayl al-Nufaylī, and he is trustworthy; al-Bukhari and the authors of the Sunan recorded his narrations.
[Abū Muʻāwiyah narrated to us].
He is Muḥammad ibn Khāzim al-Ḍarīr al-Kūfī, and he is trustworthy; the compilers of the six books recorded his narrations.
[Ḥ: And Ibn al-ʻAlāʼ narrated to us].
His statement: [Ḥ] is for shifting from one chain to another, and Ibn al-ʻAlāʼ is Muḥammad ibn al-ʻAlāʼ ibn Kurayb Abū Kurayb al-Baṣrī, and he is trustworthy; the compilers of the six books recorded his narrations.
[Ibn Idrīs narrated to us].
He is ʻAbd Allāh ibn Idrīs al-Awdī, and he is trustworthy; the compilers of the six books recorded his narrations.
[From Hishām ibn ʻUrwah].
He is Hishām ibn ʻUrwah ibn al-Zubayr, and he is trustworthy; the compilers of the six books recorded his narrations.
[From his father].
He is ʻUrwah ibn al-Zubayr ibn al-ʻAwwām, and he is a trustworthy jurist, one of the seven jurists of Madinah in the era of the Successors; the compilers of the six books recorded his narrations.
[From Ḥajjāj ibn Ḥajjāj].
Ḥajjāj ibn Ḥajjāj is acceptable; Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and al-Nasa’i recorded his hadith.
[From his father].
His father is a Companion; only this single hadith was recorded from him, and Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and al-Nasa’i recorded it.
His statement: [Al-Nufaylī said: Ḥajjāj ibn Ḥajjāj al-Aslamī].
Al-Nufaylī is his first shaykh, meaning that he ascribed him, saying: al-Aslamī. Then Abu Dawud said: [This is its wording], meaning: this hadith is the wording and narration of the first shaykh, namely al-Nufaylī.
So it may be that what is meant is the entire hadith, or that what is meant is that this addition is his wording.

P6759 - Explanation of Sunan Abu Dawud [238]
The Sacred Law has prevented combining a woman with her paternal aunt or her maternal aunt, because of what that contains of resentment and hatred that lead to severing ties and turning away between relatives. This is from the wisdom of the Sacred Law in blocking the avenues of corruption and evil.
It has come that Ali wanted to marry the daughter of Abu Jahl, so the Prophet ﷺ stood as a preacher and clarified that Fatimah is a part of him, and that he fears for her, from that, that she might be tried in her religion. In this too there is blocking the avenues of tribulations and corruption from the servants, let alone relatives.

P6760 - What is disliked to combine between them, from women

P6761 - Explanation of the hadith: “A woman is not married alongside her paternal aunt”
The compiler (may Allah Most High have mercy on him) said: [Chapter: What is disliked to combine between them, from women.
ʻAbd Allāh ibn Muḥammad al-Nufaylī narrated to us; Zuhayr narrated to us; Dāwūd ibn Abī Hind narrated to us, from ʻĀmir, from Abū Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him), that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: “A woman is not married alongside her paternal aunt, nor is a paternal aunt alongside her brother’s daughter; nor is a woman alongside her maternal aunt, nor is a maternal aunt alongside her sister’s daughter; and the elder is not married alongside the younger, nor the younger alongside the elder.”]

Abu Dawud cited what is disliked to be combined between from women, meaning: what is unlawful, because “disliked” among the earlier scholars is in the meaning of “unlawful,” as Allah Most High said: “All of that—its evil, with your Lord, is disliked” (al-Isra’ 17:38) after mentioning a number of prohibited matters. So His statement “disliked” means: unlawful.
As for the jurists’ terminology, they make the disliked to be that about which a prohibition came in a manner that is not decisive. It is what the one who leaves it is rewarded for and the one who does it is not punished for, and the Lawgiver sought its abandonment in a non-decisive manner. The unlawful is what the one who leaves it is rewarded for and the one who does it is punished for, and the Lawgiver sought its abandonment decisively. So “disliked” here is in the meaning of unlawful, because combining a woman with her paternal aunt and her maternal aunt is unlawful, and it is not disliked in the sense of discouragement, meaning that it may be done with dislike; rather, it is prohibited, so combining is not permitted. If it occurs, separation is required. Even if that occurred and then it became clear that this is an aunt or a maternal aunt, or there was ignorance of that, then separation between them is obligatory, so the latter one who came later is left, because the contract on the first is valid and the contract on the second is not valid; thus the latter is left.
What is intended by this chapter heading is to clarify what is unlawful to combine between from women. Unlawful combining is only between related women between whom combining is prohibited, such as two sisters, as has come in the Qur’an: “And that you combine between two sisters, except what has already passed” (al-Nisa’ 4:23), whether in marriage or in ownership of the right hand. So two sisters are not combined in marriage: if he marries one of the sisters, then her sister is not lawful for him unless he divorces her and she finishes her waiting period. Even during her waiting period it is not permitted for him to marry her sister, because the revocably divorced woman is a wife; so if he married her sister during her waiting period, he would have combined between the two sisters. Rather, he marries the second only when the first exits her waiting period.
It is known that the waiting period is upon women, but men “observe a waiting period” in two cases that are called “a waiting period” as a riddle: the man “observes a waiting period” when he has a woman and wants to marry her sister; it is not permissible for him to marry her sister until she finishes her waiting period, so he himself waits out this time and does not marry her sister.
The second case is when he has four wives and wants to be rid of one and marry another in her place; it is not permissible for him to marry in place of the fourth until the fourth finishes her waiting period, because if he married in her place while she is in her waiting period, he would have combined between five, since the revocably divorced woman is a wife. So these two situations are posed as riddles, and they say: the man observes a waiting period.
Likewise, in ownership of the right hand, two sisters are not combined in intercourse. As for combining between them in ownership, it is permissible, but in intercourse it is not permissible for him to combine between them.
And Allah Most High’s statement, after mentioning the prohibited women by lineage, by suckling, and by marriage ties: “And it has been permitted to you what is beyond that” (al-Nisa’ 4:24) includes the permissibility of combining a woman with her paternal aunt and combining a woman with her maternal aunt, so the Sunnah came and made an exception from that: combining a woman with her paternal aunt and combining a woman with her maternal aunt.

final_text3 = """P6750 - Does what is less than five sucklings make unlawful?

P6751 - Explanation of the hadith: “Among what Allah, Mighty and Majestic, sent down of the Qur’an were ten sucklings that make unlawful”
The compiler (may Allah Most High have mercy on him) said: [Chapter: Does what is less than five sucklings make unlawful.
ʻAbd Allāh ibn Maslamah al-Qaʻnabī narrated to us, from Mālik, from ʻAbd Allāh ibn Abī Bakr ibn Muḥammad ibn ʻAmr ibn Ḥazm, from ʻAmrah bint ʻAbd al-Raḥmān, from ʻĀʼishah (may Allah be pleased with her), that she said: Among what Allah, Mighty and Majestic, sent down of the Qur’an were ten sucklings that make unlawful; then they were abrogated by five known sucklings that make unlawful; then the Prophet ﷺ passed away while they were among what was recited of the Qur’an.]

The compiler (may Allah Most High have mercy on him) said: [Chapter: Does what is less than five sucklings make unlawful. The scholars differed regarding the suckling that causes prohibition in three views:
The first view: it is what reaches five sucklings or more. The evidence for that is this hadith which Abu Dawud cited from ʻĀʼishah (may Allah Most High be pleased with her), who said: “Among what Allah, Mighty and Majestic, sent down of the Qur’an were ten sucklings that make unlawful, then they were abrogated by five known sucklings that make unlawful; then the Prophet ﷺ passed away while they were among what was recited of the Qur’an.”
They also argued with the hadith that previously passed concerning the suckling of an adult, in which he said: “Breastfeed him five sucklings.” It is an authentic hadith, but—as is known—it is specific to Salim, the freedman of Abu Hudhayfah. In it, the five are mentioned, so it is evidence that what is considered in suckling is what reaches five sucklings.
The second view: that what makes unlawful is three sucklings or more. They infer that from the hadith that will come, namely his statement: “A single suckle does not make unlawful, nor do two suckles.” They said: its implied meaning indicates that if it is more than that, then it makes unlawful.
The third view: that little and much suckling both make unlawful, because it has come unrestricted in some texts, such as Allah Most High’s statement: “And your mothers who breastfed you, and your sisters through suckling” (al-Nisa’ 4:23). It came unrestricted. They said: thus the little and the much make unlawful.
The correct and preponderant view among these views is the view that what makes unlawful is five sucklings, because what indicates it has come from the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, as in this hadith which Abu Dawud cited, and the hadith that has already preceded concerning the suckling of an adult.
Abu Dawud cited here the hadith of ʻĀʼishah: “Among what Allah, Mighty and Majestic, sent down of the Qur’an were ten sucklings that make unlawful; then they were abrogated by five known sucklings that make unlawful; then the Prophet ﷺ passed away while they were among what was recited of the Qur’an.”
His statement: “while they” means: the five, because the pointing is to the five. There is not in the Qur’an “five sucklings make unlawful,” but in this there is an indication of the closeness of the abrogation to the death of the Messenger ﷺ, and that some people who had not received news of the abrogation continued the recitation until the abrogation reached them, due to its being close to the death of the Messenger ﷺ. So the abrogation came late.]

P6752 - Types of abrogation in the Noble Qur’an
This hadith is evidence that prohibition is only by five sucklings, and it is also evidence for two kinds among the kinds of abrogation in the Noble Qur’an, because abrogation with respect to recitation and ruling is of three divisions:
First: abrogation of both the recitation and the ruling together.
Second: abrogation of the ruling while the recitation remains.
Third: abrogation of the recitation while the ruling remains.
This hadith contains an example of two divisions: abrogation of the recitation and the ruling in the issue of ten known sucklings that make unlawful, because the ruling and the recitation were abrogated: the ruling is abrogated and the recitation is abrogated.
And “five sucklings make unlawful” was such that its recitation was abrogated while the ruling remained.
An example of the third division—abrogation of the ruling while the recitation remains—is the verse about the waiting period of the woman whose husband dies being a full year, namely Allah Most High’s statement: “And those of you who die and leave wives: a bequest for their wives, provision for a year, without expulsion” (al-Baqarah 2:240). Its ruling is abrogated while its recitation remains, and what abrogated it is the verse before it, namely that they wait four months and ten days.
Thus the divisions of abrogation with respect to recitation and ruling are three: abrogation of recitation and ruling; abrogation of recitation while the ruling remains (and the hadith we have is a witness to these two); and the third division is abrogation of the ruling while the recitation remains, as a verse.

P6754 - Explanation of the hadith: “A single suckle does not make unlawful, nor do two suckles”
The compiler (may Allah Most High have mercy on him) said: [Musaddad ibn Musarhad narrated to us; Ismāʻīl narrated to us, from Ayyūb, from Ibn Abī Mulaykah, from ʻAbd Allāh ibn al-Zubayr (may Allah be pleased with them both), from ʻĀʼishah (may Allah be pleased with her), that she said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: “A single suckle does not make unlawful, nor do two suckles.”]

Abu Dawud cited the hadith of ʻĀʼishah (may Allah be pleased with her) that the Prophet ﷺ said: “A single suckle does not make unlawful, nor do two suckles,” meaning: one suckling and two sucklings. This is explicitly stated here, but her statement, “then they were abrogated by five known sucklings that make unlawful,” indicates that what is less than it does not make unlawful, whether the one or the two explicitly stated in this hadith, or the third and the fourth that are not explicitly stated in the hadith, since they are less than the five that came in the hadith that it makes unlawful.

P6760 - What is disliked to combine between them, from women

P6761 - Explanation of the hadith: “A woman is not married alongside her paternal aunt”
The compiler (may Allah Most High have mercy on him) said: [Chapter: What is disliked to combine between them, from women.
ʻAbd Allāh ibn Muḥammad al-Nufaylī narrated to us; Zuhayr narrated to us; Dāwūd ibn Abī Hind narrated to us, from ʻĀmir, from Abū Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him), that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: “A woman is not married alongside her paternal aunt, nor is a paternal aunt alongside her brother’s daughter; nor is a woman alongside her maternal aunt, nor is a maternal aunt alongside her sister’s daughter; and the elder is not married alongside the younger, nor the younger alongside the elder.”]

Abu Dawud cited what is disliked to be combined between from women, meaning: what is unlawful, because “disliked” among the earlier scholars is in the meaning of “unlawful,” as Allah Most High said: “All of that—its evil, with your Lord, is disliked” (al-Isra’ 17:38) after mentioning a number of prohibited matters. So His statement “disliked” means: unlawful.
As for the jurists’ terminology, they make the disliked to be that about which a prohibition came in a manner that is not decisive: it is what the one who leaves it is rewarded for and the one who does it is not punished for; the Lawgiver sought its abandonment in a non-decisive manner. The unlawful is what the one who leaves it is rewarded for and the one who does it is punished for; the Lawgiver sought its abandonment decisively. So “disliked” here is in the meaning of unlawful, because combining a woman with her paternal aunt or her maternal aunt is unlawful, not disliked in the sense of being merely discouraged such that it may be done with dislike. Rather, it is forbidden: combining is not permissible. If it occurs, separation is obligatory. If it happened and then it became clear that she is an aunt (paternal or maternal), or there was ignorance of that, then separation between them is obligatory: the last one who came later is left, because the contract upon the first is valid while the contract upon the second is invalid, so the last one is left.
What is intended by this chapter heading is to clarify what is unlawful to combine between from women. Unlawful combining is only between related women between whom combining is prohibited, such as two sisters, as has come in the Qur’an: “And that you combine between two sisters, except what has already passed” (al-Nisa’ 4:23), whether in marriage or in ownership of the right hand. So two sisters are not combined in marriage: if he marries one of the sisters, then her sister is not lawful for him unless he divorces her and her waiting period ends. Even during her waiting period, it is not permissible for him to marry her sister, because the revocably divorced woman is a wife; so if he married her sister during her waiting period, he would thereby have combined between the two sisters. Rather, he marries the second only when the first exits her waiting period.
It is known that the waiting period is upon women, but men “observe a waiting period” in two cases that are called “a waiting period” as a riddle. The man “observes a waiting period” if he has a woman and wants to marry her sister: it is not permissible for him to marry her sister until she finishes her waiting period, so he himself waits out this time and does not marry her sister.
The second case is when he has four wives and wants to be rid of one and marry another in her place: it is not permissible for him to marry in place of the fourth until the fourth finishes her waiting period, because if he married in her place while she is in her waiting period, he would have combined between five, since the revocably divorced woman is a wife. So these two situations are posed as riddles, and they say: the man observes a waiting period.
Likewise, in ownership of the right hand, two sisters are not combined in intercourse. As for combining between them in ownership, it is permissible, but in intercourse it is not permissible for him to combine between them.
And Allah Most High’s statement, after mentioning the prohibited women by lineage, by suckling, and by marriage ties: “And it has been permitted to you what is beyond that” (al-Nisa’ 4:24) includes the permissibility of combining a woman with her paternal aunt and combining a woman with her maternal aunt, so the Sunnah came and made an exception from that: combining a woman with her paternal aunt and combining a woman with her maternal aunt.
"""
# checks

100-والمقصود من هذه الترجمة بيان ما يحرم أن يجمع بينه من النساء، والجمع المحرم إنما هو بين النساء القريبات المحرم الجمع بينهن، كأن تكونا أختين، كما جاء في القرآن: {وَأَنْ تَجْمَعُوا بَيْنَ الأُخْتَيْنِ إِلَّا مَا قَدْ سَلَفَ} [النساء: ٢٣] سواءٌ أكان في الزواج أم في ملك اليمين، فلا يُجمع بين الأختين في الزواج فإذا تزوج إحدى الأختين فلا تحل له أختها إلا إذا طلقها وانتهت من العدة، حتى في حال عدتها لا يجوز له أن يتزوجها؛ لأن المطلقة الرجعية زوجة، فلو تزوج أختها في حال عدتها فإنه يكون بذلك قد جمع بين الأختين، وإنما يتزوج بالثانية عندما تخرج الأولى من العدة، ومعلوم أن العدة على النساء، والرجال يعتدون في حالتين يطلق عليهما عدة على سبيل الإلغاز، فالرجل يعتد إذا كانت عنده امرأة فيريد أن يتزوج أختها، فليس له أن يتزوج أختها حتى تفرغ من العدة، فهو نفسه يتربص هذه المدة فلا يتزوج بأختها.

102-وكذلك في ملك اليمين لا يجمع بين أختين في الوطء، وأما أن يجمع بينهما في الملك فجائز، لكن الوطء ليس له أن يجمع فيه بينهما.

Translating hadith biography segment

It continues with narrations from trustworthy chains, including Ziyād b. Ayyūb, ʿĪsā b. Yūnus, and ʿAlī b. ʿĀṣim.

Translating hadith chain and complexity
The chain continues with narrators like ʿAṭāʾ b. al-Sāʾib, who is truthful but became confused, with his hadith narrated by al-Bukhari and the Sunan compilers. It then mentions Saʿīd b. Jubayr, also trustworthy and narrated by the six authors. The chain touches upon Ibn ʿAbbās, the revered cousin of the Prophet ﷺ, with a note that the hadith chain is weak despite corroborating many hadith on the martyr's washing.

Addressing the chain weaknesses and Hanzalah’s story
The hadith’s weakness stems from ʿAṭāʾ b. al-Sāʾib, who was truthful but became confused, with ʿAlī b. ʿĀṣim narrating from him afterward. ʿAlī is also truthful but prone to persistent mistakes, adding defects to this hadith. Regarding Hanzalah, the martyr known as "the one washed by angels," his washing was due to major impurity, not a precedent for all martyrs.

Clarifying proper washing and narration details
It’s important to note that if someone dies in a state of janabah, they only need one washing, not two. Similarly, the Friday bath can cover the janabah requirement.

The martyrs of Uhud were not washed, buried with their blood, and no prayer was said for them. Regarding the chain, I will transliterate the names correctly.

For names like Ibn Shihāb, I can keep it as "Ibn Shihāb" in the chain, following standard transliteration (ALA-LC). For the others—Anas b. Mālik, Usāmah b. Zayd al-Laythī—I’ll just use the established forms. Regarding commentary, there’s a discussion on washing martyrs and the funeral prayer.

Translating and explaining hadith narrators

Zayd al-Laythī is truthful but sometimes errs. The chain includes Ibn Wahb, and then the meaning of the incident with Hamza is discussed.

Explaining martyr burial and hadith context
The Prophet ﷺ asked about the slain’s Quran knowledge and arranged their burial in a single grave, with groups shrouded in one garment. Regarding Hamza’s mutilation, he said he would have left the body for birds to consume, a gesture expressing martyrdom's unique treatment. The shortage of shrouds led to shared garments and makeshift coverings.

Explaining Martyr Burial and Grave Practices
Some hadith mention how Mus'ab b. 'Umayr was buried with only a small cloth that didn’t cover his head and feet completely. The Prophet ﷺ recommended placing it on his head and using a plant, idhkhir, at his feet. The hadith also allow burying groups in one grave in circumstances of necessity.

Discussing Zayd b. al-Ḥubbāb's narrations and terminology
Zayd b. al-Ḥubbāb is recognized as truthful, and al-Bukhari recorded his narration in "The Section on Recitation." Muslim and the Sunan compilers also included his narrations. When discussing "Juz' al-Qirāʾah," it's better to translate as "The Section on Recitation" instead of using the transliteration.

Explaining hadith about burial and covering the dead
The Prophet ﷺ ordered that the slain of Uhud be buried with their blood, without washing. He would place the one with more Quran closer to the grave's niche. Commentary clarifies this hadith, with scholars agreeing on its significance in burial practices. The hadith also emphasizes covering the dead's nakedness during washing.

Clarifying chain of narration and transliteration concerns
The hadith is weak due to discontinuity between narrators—specifically between Ibn Jurayj and Ḥabīb b. Abī Thābit. Additionally, the hadith content includes multiple mentions of exposed thighs and private parts but is weak due to incomplete transmission. translation = """P10490 - Biographies of the narrators in the chain of the hadith: (The Messenger of Allah ﷺ ordered the slain of Uhud to have the iron and skins removed from them and to be buried with their blood and their garments)
His statement: [Ziyād b. Ayyūb narrated to us].
Ziyād b. Ayyūb is trustworthy; al-Bukhari, Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and al-Nasa'i narrated from him.
[And ʿĪsā b. Yūnus].
He is ʿĪsā b. Yūnus al-Ṭarsūsī; he is truthful, and Abu Dawud narrated from him.
[ʿAlī b. ʿĀṣim narrated to us].
ʿAlī b. ʿĀṣim is truthful; he makes mistakes and persists—that is, in the mistake. Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and Ibn Majah narrated from him.
[From ʿAṭāʾ b. al-Sāʾib].
ʿAṭāʾ b. al-Sāʾib is truthful; he became confused, and al-Bukhari and the compilers of the Sunan narrated his hadith.
[From Saʿīd b. Jubayr].
Saʿīd b. Jubayr is trustworthy; the authors of the six books narrated from him.
[From Ibn ʿAbbās]: he is ʿAbd Allāh b. ʿAbbās b. ʿAbd al-Muṭṭalib, the cousin of the Prophet ﷺ, one of the four Companions named ʿAbd Allāh, and one of the seven known for narrating many hadith from the Prophet ﷺ.
This hadith’s chain is weak, although not washing the martyrs is established in many hadith. The weakness in the chain is because of ʿAṭāʾ b. al-Sāʾib, for he was truthful but became confused, and ʿAlī b. ʿĀṣim is among those who narrated from him after the confusion. Then, too, ʿAlī b. ʿĀṣim is truthful, makes mistakes, and persists in the mistake. So this hadith has two defects.
The fact that Hanzalah is called “the one washed by the angels,” despite his being a martyr, may Allah be pleased with him, does not indicate that martyrs are washed, because the angels washed him due to major ritual impurity; he went out to fight while in a state of major impurity.
This does not entail that if a man dies while in a state of major impurity he should be washed twice: a washing for major impurity and a washing for the deceased. Rather, a single washing suffices. This is like the bath for Friday and the bath for major impurity: it previously passed in Sunan Abi Dawud that he said: if a man is in a state of major impurity and bathes after dawn has risen, it suffices for the Friday bath, meaning that he intends both this and that.

P10491 - Explanation of the hadith: (That the martyrs of Uhud were not washed, were buried with their blood, and no prayer was performed over them)
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Aḥmad b. Ṣāliḥ narrated to us; Ibn Wahb narrated to us; (ḥ) and Sulaymān b. Dāwūd al-Mahrī narrated to us; Ibn Wahb informed us—and this is his wording—; Usāmah b. Zayd al-Laythī informed me that Ibn Shihāb informed him that Anas b. Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated to them: (That the martyrs of Uhud were not washed, were buried with their blood, and no prayer was performed over them)].
Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Anas b. Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: “(Indeed, the martyrs of Uhud were not washed, were buried with their blood, and no prayer was performed over them).” The meaning is that they were not washed; rather, they were buried with their blood, and no prayer was performed over them. This indicates that martyrs are not washed, so that that trace remains as a sign of martyrdom in the path of Allah, Exalted and Mighty.
His statement: “(and no prayer was performed over them).” It has come in some hadith that the Prophet ﷺ prayed over Hamzah, and in some that he prayed over them all. Because of this, the scholars differed regarding the funeral prayer over the martyr: is it performed for him, or not performed for him? Imam Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, reconciled them by saying: the Muslim is given a choice between praying over them and leaving that, for if he prays over them, there is what indicates that; and if he does not pray over them, there is what indicates that. Thus the matter is one of choice. But praying over them is more fitting if possible, for it is an increase of good because of the supplication it contains.
As for washing, then—as we have known—they are not washed, so that that blood remains as a sign by which they are recognized on the Day of Resurrection.
Accordingly, praying over them is not obligatory as it is for others. For others, the prayer over him is obligatory as a communal obligation, for the funeral prayer is among the communal obligations; but as for the martyrs, it is permissible to pray over them and permissible to leave it, and praying over them is more fitting.

P10492 - Biographies of the narrators in the chain of the hadith: (That the martyrs of Uhud were not washed, were buried with their blood, and no prayer was performed over them)
His statement: [Aḥmad b. Ṣāliḥ narrated to us].
He is Aḥmad b. Ṣāliḥ al-Miṣrī, and he is trustworthy; al-Bukhari, Abu Dawud, and al-Tirmidhi in al-Shama'il narrated from him.
[Ibn Wahb narrated to us].
He is ʿAbd Allāh b. Wahb al-Miṣrī; he is trustworthy, a jurist; the authors of the six books narrated from him.
[(ḥ) and Sulaymān b. Dāwūd al-Mahrī narrated to us].
He is Sulaymān b. Dāwūd al-Mahrī al-Miṣrī; he is trustworthy; Abu Dawud and al-Nasa'i narrated from him.
[Ibn Wahb informed us, and this is his wording].
Meaning: the wording is that of Sulaymān, because Ibn Wahb narrates from him through both routes.
[Usāmah b. Zayd al-Laythī informed me].
Usāmah b. Zayd al-Laythī is truthful; he errs. Al-Bukhari narrated from him in suspended form, and Muslim and the compilers of the Sunan narrated from him.
[That Ibn Shihāb informed him].
He is Muḥammad b. Muslim b. ʿUbayd Allāh b. Shihāb al-Zuhrī; he is trustworthy; the authors of the six books narrated from him.
[That Anas b. Mālik narrated to them].
Anas b. Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him, was a Companion of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and his servant, and one of the seven known for narrating many hadith from the Prophet ﷺ.

P10493 - Explanation of the hadith: (That the Messenger of Allah ﷺ passed by Hamzah and he had been mutilated)
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [ʿUthmān b. Abī Shaybah narrated to us; Zayd—meaning Ibn al-Ḥubbāb—narrated to us; (ḥ) and Qutaybah b. Saʿīd narrated to us; Abū Ṣafwān—meaning al-Marwānī—narrated to us; from Usāmah, from al-Zuhrī, from Anas b. Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him, with the meaning: that the Messenger of Allah ﷺ passed by Hamzah, may Allah be pleased with him, and he had been mutilated, so he said: (Were it not that Ṣafiyyah, may Allah be pleased with her, would feel something in herself, I would have left him until the birds ate him, until he would be resurrected from their bellies; and the garments were few and the slain were many, so the man, and the two men, and the three were shrouded in a single garment).
Qutaybah added: (Then they were buried in a single grave, and the Messenger ﷺ used to ask: which of them has more Quran? and he would put him toward the qiblah).]
Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet ﷺ said, when he saw Hamzah and he had been mutilated: “(Were it not that Ṣafiyyah …),” and she is the paternal aunt of the Messenger and the sister of Hamzah.
His statement: “(Were it not that Ṣafiyyah would feel something in herself, I would have left him until the birds ate him)”: that is, he would leave him until he would be resurrected from their bellies. This is the reason for citing it in this chapter: namely, that the martyr is not washed, because his statement “(I would have left him)” means: I would not have washed him.
I do not know the basis for his statement: “(until the birds ate him, and until he would be resurrected from their bellies),” for it is well known that the dead—martyrs and others—are all buried in the earth. So the Messenger ﷺ saying, concerning Hamzah: “(Were it not that Ṣafiyyah would feel something in herself, I would have left him until the birds ate him, and until he would be resurrected from their bellies)”—I do not know the basis of that.
His statement: “(and the garments were few and the slain were many)”: that is, they did not have shrouds sufficient for all of them, so a group would be shrouded with a single garment. The meaning of being shrouded with a single garment is that a garment that would suffice one person would be divided between two or three; it does not mean that they were all wrapped in one garment. Rather, it would cover the head of the deceased, meaning that one begins from the side of his head, and if something remains on the side of his legs, it is covered with tree leaves or the like, as has come in some hadith in the story of Mus'ab b. ʿUmayr: they did not find anything to shroud him with except a small piece; if they put it over his head his legs would appear, and if they put it over his legs his head would appear. So the Prophet ﷺ said: “Place it over his head, and place some grass over his legs.”
In the hadith also is the permissibility of burying a group in a single grave, and that is permissible when there is need, such as when the dead are many, for then digging graves for everyone at one time is difficult. This is something the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ brought, as in this hadith.
His statement: “(Then they were buried in a single grave, and the Messenger ﷺ used to ask: which of them has more Quran? and he would put him toward the qiblah)”: this indicates the virtue of the bearer of the Quran.
It has become widespread among people to bury children beside the dead, hoping that the deceased will be shown mercy because of their proximity. This is not legislated. There is no harm in it when there is need, but when there is no need there is no basis for it. Some people do this, and you find them eager, when a man and a child die, to bury the child with the man, to “keep him company.” From where do people get these beliefs? A person is not kept company in his grave except by righteous deeds. As for anything else, nothing has come to indicate it. Rather, as is known, the one in bliss is in bliss and the one punished is punished, even if they are in a single grave: this one does not know about the punishment of that one, and that one does not know about the bliss of this one. The matters of the grave are from the matters of the intermediate realm whose modality is not known, and its modality is not sought. Rather, one must affirm everything that has come from the Prophet ﷺ even if we do not grasp the essence and the modality.

P10495 - Explanation of the hadith of praying over Hamzah after his killing, and biographies of its narrators
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [ʿAbbās al-ʿAnbarī narrated to us; ʿUthmān b. ʿUmar narrated to us; Usāmah narrated to us, from al-Zuhrī, from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: (That the Prophet ﷺ passed by Hamzah and he had been mutilated, and he did not pray over any of the martyrs besides him)].
Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Anas: “(That the Prophet ﷺ passed by Hamzah, may Allah be pleased with him, and he had been mutilated, and he did not pray over any of the martyrs besides him).” What is intended by this is that he did not pray over anyone besides him separately; otherwise, there has come what indicates that he prayed over others along with him, and that the Prophet’s prayer over Hamzah was repeated.
His statement: [ʿAbbās al-ʿAnbarī narrated to us].
He is ʿAbbās b. ʿAbd al-ʿAẓīm al-ʿAnbarī, and he is trustworthy; al-Bukhari narrated from him in suspended form, and Muslim and the compilers of the Sunan narrated from him.

[Usāmah, from al-Zuhrī, from Anas].

P10496 - Explanation of the hadith: (That the Prophet ﷺ ordered that the slain of Uhud be buried with their blood and not washed)
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Qutaybah b. Saʿīd and Yazīd b. Khālid b. Mawhab narrated to us that al-Layth narrated to them, from Ibn Shihāb, from ʿAbd al-Raḥmān b. Kaʿb b. Mālik, that Jābir b. ʿAbd Allāh, may Allah be pleased with them both, informed him: (That the Messenger of Allah ﷺ used to bring together the two men from among the slain of Uhud and say: Which of them has taken more of the Quran? When one of them was indicated to him, he would put him forward in the grave-niche, and he would say: I am a witness over these on the Day of Resurrection. And he ordered that they be buried with their blood and that they not be washed)].
Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Jābir b. ʿAbd Allāh, and it is like what came before regarding not washing the martyr: the Messenger ﷺ ordered that they be buried with their blood and not washed. In it, he would bring together the two men in a single grave, and he would ask who of them had taken more of the Quran and put him forward.

P10498 - Explanation of the hadith of burying the slain of Uhud with their blood, and bringing together two of them in a garment, and biographies of its narrators
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Sulaymān b. Dāwūd al-Mahrī narrated to us; Ibn Wahb narrated to us, from al-Layth, with this hadith in its meaning. He said: (He would bring together the two men from among the slain of Uhud in a single garment)].
The compiler cited the hadith through another route, and in it: “(that he brought together the two men from among the slain of Uhud in one garment)” at the time of shrouding, but it is as though what is intended is: in a single grave. As for a single garment, it is divided between two, as has passed in the previous hadith.
His statement: [Sulaymān b. Dāwūd al-Mahrī informed us; Ibn Wahb informed us from al-Layth with this hadith in its meaning].

P10499 - Concealing the deceased when washing him

P10500 - Explanation of the hadith: (Do not expose your thigh, and do not look at the thigh of a living person or a dead person)
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter on concealing the deceased when washing him.
ʿAlī b. Sahl al-Ramlī narrated to us; Ḥajjāj narrated to us, from Ibn Jurayj: I was informed from Ḥabīb b. Abī Thābit, from ʿĀṣim b. Ḍamrah, from ʿAlī, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet ﷺ said: (Do not expose your thigh, and do not look at the thigh of a living person or a dead person)].
Imam Abu Dawud al-Sijistani, may Allah have mercy on him, brought a chapter on concealing the deceased when washing him; meaning that his nakedness is covered when he is washed. The nakedness is from the navel to the knee, and the washing is done beneath the covering that is over the nakedness. As for what is outside the nakedness, there is no harm in it being uncovered, such as his calves and what is above his navel.
Abu Dawud, may Allah have mercy on him, related the hadith of ʿAlī, may Allah be pleased with him, ascribed to the Prophet ﷺ: “(Do not expose your thigh, and do not look at the thigh of a living person or a dead person).” The point of evidence in this hadith is his statement: “(or a dead person).” The hadith is weak because there is a break between Ibn Jurayj and Ḥabīb b. Abī Thābit; and it has also been said that there is a break between Ḥabīb b. Abī Thābit and ʿAlī. For Ḥabīb b. Abī Thābit would narrate with omitted links and conceal intermediaries, and the break between Ibn Jurayj and Ḥabīb b. Abī Thābit is clear and evident: Ibn Jurayj said, “I was informed from Ḥabīb b. Abī Thābit,” so the one who informed him is not mentioned; thus there is a deleted intermediary. So the hadith is weak.
However, mention of the thigh and the nakedness has come in multiple hadith. Shaykh al-Albani, may Allah have mercy on him, said that they reach the level of being usable as evidence when taken together. For in some hadith there is the uncovering of the Prophet’s thigh ﷺ, and in some there is mention of something about the form of his thigh and his calves. And it has come from Anas: “that his thigh ﷺ became uncovered while he was riding his mount, in an alley from the alleys of Khaybar, on the day of the conquest of Khaybar.” Some of the people of knowledge said that this uncovering was because of the intensity of the running of the horse that he ﷺ was riding. It is known that taking precaution in the religion, and acting upon what has come regarding covering the nakedness, being careful about it, not looking at it, and not exposing it, is what one should be keen on.
Some of the people of knowledge said: the nakedness is two kinds: a severe nakedness and a light nakedness. The severe nakedness is the private parts, and the light nakedness is the thighs. So a person should be keen not to expose anything of his nakedness at all, whether severe or light. Even if some of it is more severe than some, it is like a protected boundary: whoever is lax regarding the protected boundary may become lax until he reaches what is severe.
"""

final_translation = """P10490 - Biographies of the narrators in the chain of the hadith: (The Messenger of Allah ﷺ ordered the slain of Uhud to have the iron and skins removed from them and to be buried with their blood and their garments)
His statement: [Ziyād b. Ayyūb narrated to us].
Ziyād b. Ayyūb is trustworthy; al-Bukhari, Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and al-Nasa'i narrated from him.
[And ʿĪsā b. Yūnus].
He is ʿĪsā b. Yūnus al-Ṭarsūsī; he is truthful; Abu Dawud narrated from him.
[ʿAlī b. ʿĀṣim narrated to us].
ʿAlī b. ʿĀṣim is truthful; he makes mistakes and persists—that is, in the mistake. Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and Ibn Majah narrated from him.
[From ʿAṭāʾ b. al-Sāʾib].
ʿAṭāʾ b. al-Sāʾib is truthful; he became confused, and al-Bukhari and the compilers of the Sunan narrated his hadith.
[From Saʿīd b. Jubayr].
Saʿīd b. Jubayr is trustworthy; the authors of the six books narrated from him.
[From Ibn ʿAbbās]: he is ʿAbd Allāh b. ʿAbbās b. ʿAbd al-Muṭṭalib, the cousin of the Prophet ﷺ, one of the four Companions named ʿAbd Allāh, and one of the seven known for narrating many hadith from the Prophet ﷺ.
This hadith’s chain is weak, although not washing the martyrs is established in many hadith. The weakness in the chain is because of ʿAṭāʾ b. al-Sāʾib, for he was truthful but became confused, and ʿAlī b. ʿĀṣim is among those who narrated from him after the confusion. Then, too, ʿAlī b. ʿĀṣim is truthful, makes mistakes, and persists in the mistake. So this hadith has two defects.
The fact that Hanzalah is called “the one washed by the angels,” despite his being a martyr, may Allah be pleased with him, does not indicate that martyrs are washed, because the angels washed him due to major ritual impurity; he went out to fight while in a state of major impurity.
This does not entail that if a man dies while in a state of major ritual impurity he should be washed twice: a washing for major ritual impurity and a washing for the deceased. Rather, a single washing suffices. This is like the bath for Friday and the bath for major ritual impurity. It previously passed in Sunan Abi Dawud that he said: if a man is in a state of major ritual impurity and bathes after dawn has risen, it suffices for the Friday bath, meaning that he intends both this and that.

P10491 - Explanation of the hadith: (That the martyrs of Uhud were not washed, were buried with their blood, and no prayer was performed over them)
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Aḥmad b. Ṣāliḥ narrated to us; Ibn Wahb narrated to us; (ḥ) and Sulaymān b. Dāwūd al-Mahrī narrated to us; Ibn Wahb informed us—and this is his wording—; Usāmah b. Zayd al-Laythī informed me that Ibn Shihāb informed him that Anas b. Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated to them: (That the martyrs of Uhud were not washed, were buried with their blood, and no prayer was performed over them)].
Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Anas b. Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: [(Indeed, the martyrs of Uhud were not washed, were buried with their blood, and no prayer was performed over them)]. The meaning is that they were not washed; rather, they were buried with their blood, and no prayer was performed over them. This indicates that martyrs are not washed, so that that trace remains as a sign of martyrdom in the path of Allah, Exalted and Mighty.
His statement: [(and no prayer was performed over them)]. It has come in some hadith that the Prophet ﷺ prayed over Hamzah, and in some that he prayed over them all. Because of this, the scholars differed regarding the funeral prayer over the martyr: is it prayed over him, or is it not prayed over him? Imam Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, reconciled them by saying: the Muslim is given a choice between praying over them and leaving that. If he prays over them, there has come what indicates that; and if he does not pray over them, there has come what indicates that. So the matter is one of choice. But praying over them is more fitting, if possible, for it is an additional good, because it includes supplication.
As for washing, then—as we have known—they are not washed, so that that blood remains as a sign by which they are recognized on the Day of Resurrection.
Accordingly, praying over them is not obligatory as it is for others. For others, the prayer over him is obligatory as a communal obligation, for the funeral prayer is among the communal obligations. But as for the martyrs, it is permissible to pray over them and permissible to leave it, and praying over them is more fitting.

P10492 - Biographies of the narrators in the chain of the hadith: (That the martyrs of Uhud were not washed, were buried with their blood, and no prayer was performed over them)
His statement: [Aḥmad b. Ṣāliḥ narrated to us].
He is Aḥmad b. Ṣāliḥ al-Miṣrī, and he is trustworthy; al-Bukhari, Abu Dawud, and al-Tirmidhi in al-Shama'il narrated from him.
[Ibn Wahb narrated to us].
He is ʿAbd Allāh b. Wahb al-Miṣrī, and he is trustworthy, a jurist; the authors of the six books narrated from him.
[(ḥ) and Sulaymān b. Dāwūd al-Mahrī narrated to us].
He is Sulaymān b. Dāwūd al-Mahrī al-Miṣrī, and he is trustworthy; Abu Dawud and al-Nasa'i narrated from him.
[Ibn Wahb informed us, and this is his wording].
Meaning: the wording is Sulaymān’s, because Ibn Wahb narrates from him through both routes.
[Usāmah b. Zayd al-Laythī informed me].
Usāmah b. Zayd al-Laythī is truthful; he errs. Al-Bukhari narrated from him in suspended form, and Muslim and the compilers of the Sunan narrated from him.
[That Ibn Shihāb informed him].
He is Muḥammad b. Muslim b. ʿUbayd Allāh b. Shihāb al-Zuhrī, and he is trustworthy; the authors of the six books narrated from him.
[That Anas b. Mālik narrated to them].
Anas b. Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him, was a Companion of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and his servant, and one of the seven known for narrating many hadith from the Prophet ﷺ.

P10493 - Explanation of the hadith: (That the Messenger of Allah ﷺ passed by Hamzah and he had been mutilated)
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [ʿUthmān b. Abī Shaybah narrated to us; Zayd—meaning Ibn al-Ḥubbāb—narrated to us; (ḥ) and Qutaybah b. Saʿīd narrated to us; Abū Ṣafwān—meaning al-Marwānī—narrated to us; from Usāmah, from al-Zuhrī, from Anas b. Mālik, may Allah be pleased with him, with the meaning: that the Messenger of Allah ﷺ passed by Hamzah, may Allah be pleased with him, and he had been mutilated, so he said: (Were it not that Ṣafiyyah, may Allah be pleased with her, would feel something in herself, I would have left him until the birds ate him, until he would be resurrected from their bellies. And the garments were few and the slain were many, so the man, and the two men, and the three would be shrouded with the single garment).
Qutaybah added: (Then they were buried in a single grave, and the Messenger ﷺ used to ask: which of them has more Quran? and he would put him toward the qiblah).]
Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet ﷺ said, when he saw Hamzah and he had been mutilated: (Were it not that Ṣafiyyah …), and she is the paternal aunt of the Messenger and the sister of Hamzah.
His statement: (Were it not that Ṣafiyyah would feel something in herself, I would have left him until the birds ate him): that is, he would leave him until he would be resurrected from their bellies. This is the reason for citing it in this chapter: namely, that the martyr is not washed, because his statement (I would have left him) means: I would not have washed him.
I do not know the basis for his statement: (until the birds ate him, and until he would be resurrected from their bellies). For it is well known that the dead—martyrs and others—are all buried in the earth. So the Messenger ﷺ saying, concerning Hamzah: (Were it not that Ṣafiyyah would feel something in herself, I would have left him until the birds ate him, and until he would be resurrected from their bellies)—I do not know the basis of that.
His statement: (and the garments were few and the slain were many) means that they did not have shrouds sufficient for all of them, so a group would be shrouded with the single garment. The meaning of being shrouded with the single garment is that a garment that would suffice one person would be divided between two or three; it does not mean that they were wrapped in a single garment. Rather, it would cover the head of the deceased, meaning that one begins from the side of his head, and if something remains on the side of his legs, it is covered with leaves or the like, as has come in some hadith in the story of Mus'ab b. Umayr: they did not find anything to shroud him with except a small piece, so if they placed it on his head his legs became uncovered, and if they placed it on his legs his head became uncovered. So the Prophet ﷺ said: (Place it on his head, and place some grass on his legs).
In the hadith also is the permissibility of burying a group in a single grave, and that is permissible when there is need, such as when the dead are many and it is difficult to dig graves for everyone at one time. This is something the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ brought, as in this hadith.
His statement: (Then they were buried in a single grave, and the Messenger ﷺ used to ask: which of them has more Quran? and he would put him toward the qiblah): this indicates the virtue of the bearer of the Quran.
It has become widespread among people to bury children beside the dead, hoping that the deceased will be shown mercy because of their proximity. This is not legislated. There is no harm in it when there is need, but when there is no need there is no basis for it. Some people do this, and you find them eager, when a man and a child die, to bury the child with the man, to “keep him company.” From where do people get these beliefs? A person is not kept company in his grave except by righteous deeds. As for other than that, nothing has come indicating it. Rather, as is well known, the one who is granted bliss is in bliss, and the one who is punished is punished, even if they are in a single grave. This one does not know about the punishment of that one, and that one does not know about the bliss of this one. The matters of the grave are among the matters of the intermediate realm whose modality is not known, and its modality is not investigated. Rather, one must believe everything that has come from the Prophet ﷺ, even if we do not grasp the reality and the manner.

P10494 - Biographies of the narrators in the chain of the hadith: (That the Messenger of Allah ﷺ passed by Hamzah and he had been mutilated)

They have been mentioned.

P10495 - Explanation of the hadith of praying over Hamzah after his killing, and biographies of its narrators

P10496 - Explanation of the hadith: (That the Prophet ﷺ ordered that the slain of Uhud be buried with their blood and not washed)

P10498 - Explanation of the hadith of burying the slain of Uhud with their blood, and bringing together two of them in a garment, and biographies of its narrators
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Sulaymān b. Dāwūd al-Mahrī narrated to us; Ibn Wahb narrated to us, from al-Layth, with this hadith in its meaning. He said: (He would bring together the two men from among the slain of Uhud in a single garment)].

P10499 - Concealing the deceased when washing him

P10500 - Explanation of the hadith: (Do not expose your thigh, and do not look at the thigh of a living person or a dead person)
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter on concealing the deceased when washing him.
ʿAlī b. Sahl al-Ramlī narrated to us; Ḥajjāj narrated to us; from Ibn Jurayj: I was informed from Ḥabīb b. Abī Thābit, from ʿĀṣim b. The nakedness is from the navel to the knee, and the washing is done beneath the covering that is over the nakedness. As for what is outside the nakedness, there is no harm in it being uncovered, such as his calves and what is above his navel.
Abu Dawud, may Allah have mercy on him, related the hadith of ʿAlī, may Allah be pleased with him, ascribed to the Prophet ﷺ: (Do not expose your thigh, and do not look at the thigh of a living person or a dead person). Some of the people of knowledge said: the nakedness is two kinds: a severe nakedness and a light nakedness. The severe nakedness is the private parts, and the light nakedness is the thighs. So a person should be keen not to expose anything of his nakedness at all, whether severe or light. Revising hadith transliteration guidelines
final3 = """P13586 - What has been narrated regarding the aqbiyah

P13587 - Explanation of the hadith: (The Messenger of Allah ﷺ distributed aqbiyah)
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter: What has been narrated regarding the aqbiyah.
Qutaybah ibn Saʿīd and Yazīd ibn Khālid ibn Mawhab narrated to us—to the same meaning—that al-Layth (meaning: Ibn Saʿd) narrated to them, from ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿUbayd Allāh ibn Abī Mulaykah, from al-Miswar ibn Makhramah, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he said: “The Messenger of Allah ﷺ distributed aqbiyah and did not give Makhramah anything. So Makhramah said: ‘O my son! Come, let us go to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ.’ So I went with him. He said: ‘Go in and call him for me.’ He said: So I called him. Then he came out to him while wearing one of those coats. He said: ‘I saved this for you.’ He said: So he looked at it—Ibn Mawhab added: Makhramah; then the two of them agreed—they said: Makhramah was pleased.” Qutaybah said: From Ibn Abī Mulaykah; he did not name him]. 

The aqbiyah are a garment said to be tight-fitting, from the clothing of the non-Arabs; and this is the qabā, with lengthening (madd) and without hamzah. Ibn Ḥajar said in Fath al-Bari: it is a tight garment from the clothing of the non-Arabs.

Abu Dawud cited the hadith of al-Miswar ibn Makhramah, may Allah be pleased with him, that his father said to him: Let us go to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, because aqbiyah had come to him and he did not give Makhramah anything; meaning: he did not send him any of them, even though he had set some aside for him, saved for him one coat, and prepared that for him.

His statement: “he did not give,” meaning: he did not send him anything, but he had kept something for him to give him, as becomes clear from his ﷺ words with Makhramah after he came to him.

So Makhramah asked his son al-Miswar to go with him to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. When they came, he said: “Go in and call him for me,” meaning: so that he would come out to him and speak with him, for someone may be with him and he does not want to speak, in front of people, regarding a matter such as this. So he came out to him wearing one of those coats, and he said: “I saved this for you,” meaning: I kept it back and stored it for you.

[He said: So he looked at it; Ibn Mawhab added: Makhramah].
Meaning: he is the doer of “looked,” i.e., Ibn Mawhab said: “So Makhramah looked at it,” and he mentioned the subject of “looked,” and that it is an explicit noun.
As for Qutaybah, who is the second teacher, he did not mention the subject as an explicit noun.

[Then the two of them agreed; they said: Makhramah was pleased].
The phrase “Makhramah was pleased” could be that the one who said it was the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and it could be that Makhramah said it. The closer is that Makhramah is the one who said it, meaning: I have become pleased.
And his name was mentioned explicitly in place of the pronoun.
Some manuscripts contain an interrogative: “Is Makhramah pleased?”
So if the interrogative is established, then this is from the statement of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ.
And the interrogative strengthens the possibility that the speaker is the Messenger of Allah ﷺ in the narration in which no interrogative is mentioned.

[Qutaybah said: from Ibn Abī Mulaykah; he did not name him].
Meaning: the one who named him was the second teacher, namely Ibn Mawhab. As for Qutaybah, he said: “from Ibn Abī Mulaykah” and did not name him. But Ibn Mawhab named him and named his father, saying: ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿUbayd Allāh ibn Abī Mulaykah.

P13588 - Biographies of the narrators in the isnad of the hadith: (The Messenger of Allah ﷺ distributed aqbiyah)
His statement: [Qutaybah ibn Saʿīd narrated to us].
Qutaybah ibn Saʿīd ibn Jamīl ibn Ṭarīf al-Baghlānī, trustworthy (thiqah); the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[And Yazīd ibn Khālid ibn Mawhab].
Yazīd ibn Khālid ibn Mawhab is trustworthy (thiqah); Abu Dawud, al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah narrated from him.
[To the same meaning, that al-Layth].
“To the same meaning,” i.e., that their two narrations agree in meaning.
“That al-Layth,” and he is al-Layth ibn Saʿd al-Miṣrī, trustworthy (thiqah); the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[He narrated to them from ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿUbayd Allāh ibn Abī Mulaykah].
ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿUbayd Allāh ibn Abī Mulaykah is trustworthy (thiqah); the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[From al-Miswar ibn Makhramah].
Al-Miswar ibn Makhramah, may Allah be pleased with them both; he is a Companion, and the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
This isnad is four-link, and it is among the highest isnads with Abu Dawud.

P13589 - Sharh Sunan Abi Dawud [452]
Garments of fame call a person to arrogance and to elevating himself above people. In it there is extravagance, vanity, and distinction over others, and it is prohibited; its wearer is exposed to the threat and to the Fire.
As for clothing that is high-priced, it differs from person to person; one looks at its motives, its reasons, and its details. The particulars of its rulings are explained in this entry.

P13590 - What has been narrated regarding wearing the garment of fame

P13591 - Explanation of the hadith: (Whoever wears a garment of fame, Allah will clothe him on the Day of Resurrection with one like it)
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Chapter concerning wearing the garment of fame.
Muḥammad ibn ʿĪsā narrated to us, Abū ʿAwānah narrated to us. H.
And Muḥammad—meaning Ibn ʿĪsā—narrated to us, from Sharīk, from ʿUthmān ibn Abī Zurʿah, from al-Muhājir al-Shāmī, from Ibn ʿUmar, may Allah be pleased with them both—he said in the hadith of Sharīk: he raises it—he said: “Whoever wears a garment of fame, Allah will clothe him on the Day of Resurrection with a garment like it.” Added, from Abū ʿAwānah: “Then the Fire will blaze in it.”]. 

What is meant by fame is that which a person becomes famous for and by which he distinguishes himself from others. It may lead to arrogance because it is expensive, high-priced, and precious, so along with that there is self-aggrandizement, haughtiness, and elevation over people. It may also be something that draws attention, in his distinctive clothing that differs from the clothing of the people of his land and differs from the clothing of his folk.

He, may Allah have mercy on him, cited the hadith of ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿUmar, may Allah be pleased with them both, as raised (marfu') to the Prophet ﷺ: “Whoever wears a garment of fame, Allah will clothe him on the Day of Resurrection with one like it,” meaning: something by which he becomes famous, but it is in blame and in evil.

[Added, from Abū ʿAwānah: “Then the Fire will blaze in it.”]
Meaning: this garment by which he becomes famous, the Fire will blaze in it, i.e., he will be punished by this garment, or by the like of this garment which he wore and by which arrogance occurred from him. For this reason, in some narrations there occurs: “a garment of humiliation,” meaning: just as arrogance occurred from him, so humiliation will occur for him in the Hereafter in return for that; he will be made to wear a garment of humiliation, so in it there is abasement for him. And in it also is his punishment by it, since in this narration it says: “Then the Fire will blaze in it.”

The garment of fame may be with intent, and it falls under the threat; and it may be without intent, and one fears for him that he may be included in the threat as well, in addition to the fact that he may be suspected regarding his intellect because of that outfit of his.

P13592 - Biographies of the narrators in the isnad of the hadith: (Whoever wears a garment of fame, Allah will clothe him on the Day of Resurrection with one like it)
His statement: [Muḥammad ibn ʿĪsā narrated to us].
Muḥammad ibn ʿĪsā al-Ṭabbāʿ, trustworthy (thiqah); al-Bukhari narrated from him in mu'allaq form, and Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi in al-Shama'il, al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah.
[From Abū ʿAwānah].
Abū ʿAwānah al-Waḍḍāḥ ibn ʿAbd Allāh al-Yashkurī, trustworthy (thiqah); the authors of the Six Books narrated from him.
[H and Muḥammad—meaning Ibn ʿĪsā—narrated to us].
He is the first teacher.
[From Sharīk].
Sharīk ibn ʿAbd Allāh al-Nakhaʿī al-Kūfī, the judge: truthful (saduq), but he makes many mistakes; his memory changed because he took up the judgeship. His hadith was narrated by al-Bukhari in mu'allaq form, by Muslim, and by the authors of the Sunan.
[From ʿUthmān ibn Abī Zurʿah].
ʿUthmān ibn Abī Zurʿah is trustworthy (thiqah); al-Bukhari and the authors of the Sunan narrated from him.
[From al-Muhājir al-Shāmī].
Al-Muhājir al-Shāmī—he is al-Muhājir ibn ʿAmr—is acceptable (maqbul); Abu Dawud, al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah narrated from him.
[From Ibn ʿUmar].
He is ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿUmar ibn al-Khaṭṭāb, may Allah be pleased with them both, the eminent Companion, one of the four ʿAbadilah among the Companions, and one of the seven known for abundant narration from the Prophet ﷺ.

[He said in the hadith of Sharīk: he raises it].
It is as though—on this—there is no mention of raising it in the first route, and as though it is stopped (mawquf) at Ibn ʿUmar. As for Sharīk, in the second route he said: “he raises it,” meaning: Ibn ʿUmar attributes it to the Prophet ﷺ; because the phrase “he raises it” is equivalent to “He said: the Messenger of Allah ﷺ,” or “I heard the Messenger of Allah ﷺ.”

[Added, from Abū ʿAwānah: “Then the Fire will blaze in it.”]
Meaning: an addition in the first route: “Then the Fire will blaze in it.” This addition is not in Sharīk’s route; rather it is in the route of Abū ʿAwānah, which is the first route.

The isnad has been spoken about, and al-Albani graded it authentic (sahih).
Sharīk is coupled (maqrūn), and Abū ʿAwānah is trustworthy (thiqah), but in it is al-Muhājir al-Shāmī, who is acceptable (maqbul) according to the method of al-Hafiz; meaning that he is accepted in supporting narrations (mutaba'at). And this hadith is from a single route.

P13593 - Biographies of the narrators in another route for the hadith: (Whoever wears a garment of fame, Allah will clothe him on the Day of Resurrection)
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [Musaddad narrated to us; he said: Abū ʿAwānah narrated to us; he said: “a garment of humiliation.”].
This is a third teacher for Abu Dawud in this hadith, and he is Musaddad ibn Musarhad, trustworthy (thiqah); al-Bukhari, Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi, and al-Nasa'i narrated from him.
[Abū ʿAwānah narrated to us].
He has already been mentioned in the first route.

P13594 - Explanation of the hadith: (Whoever imitates a people is one of them)
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [ʿUthmān ibn Abī Shaybah narrated to us, Abū al-Naḍr narrated to us, ʿAbd al-Raḥmān ibn Thābit narrated to us, Ḥassān ibn ʿAṭiyyah narrated to us, from Abū Munīb al-Jurashī, from Ibn ʿUmar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: “Whoever imitates a people is one of them.”]. 

Abu Dawud cited the hadith of Ibn ʿUmar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Prophet ﷺ said: “Whoever imitates a people is one of them.” This is censure of one who imitates the disbelievers, because outward imitation may lead to inclination inwardly and in the heart.

What is intended by that is imitation in something that is among their distinguishing characteristics and something that is among their hallmarks. As for matters that are sought in Islam—such as preparing strength and giving care to beneficial affairs—then this is something sought; but the prohibited and forbidden matter is what is in issues of clothing or appearance and the like.

His statement: “Whoever imitates a people is one of them” is severe censure regarding one who is like that.

He placed this hadith under the chapter of wearing the garment of fame, meaning that the compiler considers wearing the clothing of the disbelievers to be considered wearing the garment of fame; and this is possible. For if the people of his land wear a certain clothing among the clothing of the Muslims, and then he appears among them in other clothing—whether it is for disbelievers or for others—then that is a garment of fame: an outfit that brings together two evil matters. One of them is that it is the clothing of disbelievers. The other is that it is strange to people, and in it there is fame among people; thus he gathered between two calamities."""

Translating legal terms and explanation
When a man owns a slave woman, she is lawful for him for both service and sexual enjoyment. He owns her sexual access (baḍʿ) and her person and labor. If he marries her off, the benefit of intercourse (baḍʿ) transfers to the husband, but the ownership of service remains with the original owner.

"How was she performing the prayer?! How could days pass without purification and prayer? And if she prayed, how was her prayer? A woman who does not pray—may Allah protect us from that—is in a more serious situation than fasting! Some may fast but neglect prayer. Prayer is more important than fasting."

“If a woman is ignorant or has menstruation for the first time and is unaware, she may pray. For Jibril’s description, I’ll translate as "a huge created being filling the horizon with 600 wings." Lastly, "وَرَضِيتُ لَكُمُ الإِسْلامَ دِينًا" will be "and I am pleased with Islam as the religion for you" from Surah al-Ma'idah.

Translating key terms and proper names
I’ll translate “إِنَّ الدِّينَ عِنْدَ اللَّهِ الإِسْلامُ” as “Indeed the religion with Allah is Islam” (Surah Al 'Imran 19) while avoiding diacritics in surah names. “عز وجل” will be translated as “Allah, Mighty and Majestic” or “Most High.” “رحمه الله تعالى” translates as “may Allah, Most High, have mercy on him.”

For narrators, I’ll use ALA-LC transliteration, like “ʿUbayd Allāh ibn Muʿādh,” but for Prophet Muhammad, no diacritics are needed since he’s part of the content. “المصنف” refers to the compiler, likely Abu Dawud in this case.

Ensuring no Arabic characters and final translation details
I’ll maintain consistency by keeping IDs and numeric prefixes (e.g., 528) using Western numerals, converting Arabic numerals (٥٢٨ to 528). Arabic characters or curly brackets will be avoided. In translations, "رضي الله تعالى عنه وأرضاه" will be translated into English, maintaining respect without Arabic. I'll also avoid diacritic-like Latin letters (ʿ, ḥ) where unnecessary. Now, I’ll focus on creating clean content segments for clarity and accurate translation of references and text.

Clarifying the role of scholars and the concept of deviation
The people of knowledge are referred to when religious matters arise, especially when there are deviations or corruption in practices. In the hadith about Jibril, the response is that some individuals weren't completely deviant—though they held some good qualities, their innovation led to corruption in their practices.

Examples from the Prophet ﷺ about marriage and teaching
When a woman consulted the Prophet ﷺ about two suitors, he explained their conditions rather than their religious roles. He focused on what mattered—Muawiyah’s poverty and Abu Jahm’s behavior. This shows prioritizing relevant traits in decision-making. Similarly, mentions of names and addressing fathers show permissible practices in specific contexts.

Explanation of acting and the hadith on religion's ranks
Lying for amusement, such as in acting, contradicts reality and isn't allowed. In explaining the hadith of Jibril, three ranks in religion are outlined: Islam, iman, and the highest, ihsan. Ihsan involves sensing Allah's presence and majesty, which none can fully attain except whom Allah honors.

Explaining hadith on qadar, prayer, and terminology choices
The hadith of Jibril emphasizes belief in qadar (divine preordainment), essential for the acceptance of good deeds. Words like "ilah" represent a deity, so "there is no ilah but Allah" will be used. In translating "الشهادتين", "the two testimonies of faith" fits best, clarified if needed, avoiding Arabic. Similarly, "wali" can be translated to "a close ally of Allah."

Handling translation considerations for names and terminology
When translating terms like "الإيمان" and "الإسلام," we’ll ensure distinction between them, as they hold different meanings. I’ll use proper titles like "names and attributes" for "وأسمائه وصفاته" and "lordship" for "الربوبية". For consistency, we'll also stick to ALA-LC when transliterating narrators' names in the chain but avoid applying it to non-chain names.

Final considerations for translation accuracy
For the name "ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿUmar," we'll stick with ALA-LC transliteration, ensuring proper diacritics are included. The same goes for other narrators like "ʿUmar ibn al-Khaṭṭāb." However, for the Prophet's name, we won't use ALA-LC in the matn, only in the isnad. I'll keep translations direct and without extra disclaimers.
